Quantum theory is often described as a theory of linear operators on complex Hilbert spaces. This description is useful, but it is not complete. We provide a categorical description of quantum theory that is purely categorical and does not presuppose any analytical structure. The axioms are designed to be as simple as possible, and we believe that they are the simplest possible. The theory is equivalent to the theory of continuous linear operators on Hilbert spaces, but it is more general. It is also more natural, and it leads to a more natural description of quantum theory.

The Myxozoa are a group of microscopic parasites that have been the subject of intense study for over a century. Despite this, the origin of the group remains elusive, and the group is poorly understood. Here, we present a genomic and transcriptomic analysis of two myxozoans and a cnidarian parasite, and we show that the myxozoan body plan is the result of a dramatic reduction in gene content and size. Our results provide insights into the origin of the Myxozoa and the evolution of the parasitic lifestyle.

In this study, we show that SARS-CoV-2 is able to efficiently block STAT1 and STAT2 nuclear translocation in order to impair transcriptional induction of IFN-stimulated genes. Voltage-gated proton channels are involved in many physiological processes, such as pH homeostasis and the innate immune response. In this study, we use the voltage clamp fluorometry technique to identify the molecular mechanism of Zn2+ inhibition of Hv1. We find that Zn2+ binds to both the activated closed and resting closed states of the Hv1 channel, thereby inhibiting both voltage sensor motion and gate opening. These effects are similar in monomeric and dimeric Hv1 channels, suggesting that the Zn2+-binding sites are localized within each subunit of the dimeric Hv1. Elucidating the molecular mechanism of how Zn2+ inhibits Hv1 will further our understanding of Hv1 function and might provide valuable information for future drug development for Hv1 channels. The world’s population is expected to grow to 10 billion by the middle of the 21st century, and the demand for food is expected to increase by 50% to meet this demand. This study shows that, absent changes in temperature variability or breeding gains in heat tolerance, the coefficient of variation of maize yields will increase to values much larger than present-day values, and the probability of simultaneous production losses greater than 10% in any given year will increase substantially. These results highlight the need for investments in breeding for heat tolerance, especially in the major maize-producing and -exporting countries.

The extent to which large mammalian herbivores partition food resources is important for understanding the mechanisms of biodiversity and the potential impacts of herbivore overabundance. However, the extent to which species differ in their diets is difficult to quantify because of the time and labor required to identify species-specific plant remains. We show that DNA metabarcoding can be used to quantify diet breadth, composition, and overlap for seven species of large herbivores in a semiarid African savanna. We found that diet composition differed between species, even when they were matched in body size and digestive physiology. These results suggest that coarse trophic categorizations may generate misleading conclusions about competition and coexistence in large herbivore assemblages, and that the diversity of large herbivores may be more tightly linked to plant diversity than is currently recognized. This study highlights the importance of diet composition in determining the structure of large herbivore assemblages.

The COVID-19 pandemic has had a devastating impact on small businesses, many of which are on the brink of closure. We conducted a survey of more than 5,800 small businesses to understand the impact of the crisis on their operations and finances. We find that many businesses have already laid off workers and are closing. Many businesses are financially fragile, with only a few weeks of cash on hand. Many businesses plan to apply for loans under the CARES Act, but anticipate problems with accessing the program.

Plastic debris is one of the most visible consequences of human activities in the ocean. However, the magnitude of the problem is still unclear. We show that the global load of floating plastic debris is far less than expected, mostly accumulating in the convergence zones of the five subtropical gyres. However, the size distribution of the debris points at important size-selective sinks removing millimeter-sized fragments of floating plastic on a large scale. This sink may involve a combination of fast nano-fragmentation of the microplastic into particles of microns or smaller, their transference to the ocean interior by food webs and ballasting processes, and processes yet to be discovered. Resolving the fate of the missing plastic debris is of fundamental importance to determine the nature and significance of the impacts of plastic pollution in the ocean.

The origin of the solar system is one of the most important questions in astronomy. The solar system formed from the aggregation of dust particles in the interstellar medium. The dust particles were exposed to a high flux of energetic particles, which can be used to determine the age of the dust particles. We determined the ages of 40 large presolar silicon carbide grains extracted from the Murchison meteorite. The grains have ages of <300 Ma and up to >1 Ga, which is an indication that the solar system formed from the aggregation of dust particles in the interstellar medium. The grains were exposed to a high flux of energetic particles in the interstellar medium.

The global fishing fleet has doubled in size since 1950, and the motorized fleet has expanded rapidly. The effective catch per unit of effort has decreased, showing the increasing pressure of fisheries on ocean resources. The effective CPUE of most countries in 2015 was a fifth of its 1950s value, which was compared with a global decline in abundance. There are signs, however, of stabilization and more effective management in recent years, with a reduction in fleet sizes in developed countries. Based on historical patterns and allowing for the slowing rate of expansion, 1 million more motorized vessels could join the global fleet by midcentury as developing countries continue to transition away from subsistence fisheries, challenging sustainable use of fisheries' resources.

In this study, we show that the ability to provide energy to the mother during pregnancy is a strong factor in determining the reproductive output of mammals. Multiple system atrophy (MSA) is a sporadic neurodegenerative disorder that affects the autonomic nervous system and the basal ganglia. The disease is characterized by the accumulation of alpha-synuclein (α-syn) aggregates in oligodendrocytes, the cells that produce myelin in the central nervous system. We show here that the caspase-1 inhibitor VX-765, which is currently in phase II clinical trials for the treatment of epilepsy, is able to reduce the load of α-syn in oligodendrocytes and to protect neurons in a mouse model of MSA. These results suggest that VX-765 could be a promising candidate for the treatment of MSA. This study provides an in vivo proof of concept for the potential of VX-765 to slow down the progression of MSA. This study also provides a rationale for the use of caspase-1 inhibitors in the treatment of other neurodegenerative disorders. (PsycINFO Database Record

The endothelium is the lining of the blood vessels and is the interface between the blood and the tissues. It is the primary regulator of blood flow, inflammation, and hemostasis. The endothelium is composed of a single layer of cells, and each cell is specialized to perform a specific function. The endothelium is the target of many diseases, and it is important to understand how it works. Here, we show that the endothelium is a highly connected network of cells, and that the network is organized in a way that allows for efficient communication between cells. This organization may be important for the endothelium to control cardiovascular activity.

The COVID-19 pandemic has generated enormous data challenges, especially for public health researchers and policy makers. We describe the COVIDcast API, a data platform that provides open access to a wide range of COVID-19 signals, including many that are not available from traditional sources. The data are available at a fine geographic resolution and are updated daily. The data are available through the API and accompanying R and Python software packages. We hope that the COVIDcast API will be useful to researchers and policy makers, and that it will encourage the development of new applications and services.

The selectivity filter is the narrowest part of the channel’s pore and is the site of ion conduction. The selectivity filter is also the site of the activation gate, which is responsible for the opening of the channel. We have identified a key residue that is involved in the communication between the activation gate and the selectivity filter. We have shown that this residue is crucial for the allosteric communication between the two gates and that it is essential for the proper functioning of the channel.

The gut microbiome of herbivores is a dynamic community that is influenced by the host and the environment. The role of the gut microbiome in the health of the host is not fully understood, but it is thought to be important in the regulation of the host immune system. This study provides a resource of natural products from anaerobic fungi that inhabit the digestive tracts of herbivores. These fungi are a potential source of new bioactive compounds that could be used to regulate the composition of the gut microbiome and, in turn, the health of the host.

Social dominance is a fundamental aspect of social groups, but whether personality traits may predispose individuals to a particular rank remains unclear. Here we show that anxiety directly influences social dominance in male outbred rats and identify an important mediating role for mitochondrial function in the nucleus accumbens. We provide evidence that mitochondrial function in the nucleus accumbens is crucial for social behavior and that this brain region is a potential marker and avenue of treatment for anxiety-related social disorders. Our findings highlight the importance of brain energy metabolism in social behavior and point to mitochondrial function in the nucleus accumbens as a potential marker and avenue of treatment for anxiety-related social disorders. This work provides a new perspective on the role of the brain in social behavior and may lead to the development of new treatments for anxiety disorders. (PsycINFO Database Record

The design of mechanical structures with desired behaviors is of great importance for the development of functional devices. However, the use of a single material phase and the design of complex structures are often limited by the restricted design space and potential failure to achieve specific target behaviors. Here, we propose a synthesis method of composite structures composed of multiple material phases to precisely achieve arbitrary and extreme prescribed responses under large deformations. The structures are digitally synthesized with the aid of a machine-learning algorithm, and the multimaterial fabrication strategy is used to manufacture the structures. The discovered structures exhibit organic shapes and motions with irregular distributions of material phases. Within the structures, different materials play distinct roles yet seamlessly collaborate through sophisticated deformation mechanisms to produce the target behaviors. The proposed synthesis, multimaterial fabrication, and heteroassembly strategy can be utilized to design function-oriented and situation-specific mechanical devices for a wide range of applications. The hemoglobin system is a key regulator of the timing of development and differentiation in the human body. Here we show that the insulin-like growth factor 2 mRNA-binding protein 1 (IGF2BP1) is expressed in the human fetus and is down-regulated in the adult. We demonstrate that IGF2BP1 mediates posttranscriptional regulation of hemoglobin expression in human erythroid tissues. These results suggest a mechanism for chronoregulation of fetal and adult hemoglobin expression in humans. This mechanism may be important for the timing of development and differentiation in the human body.

Cancer is the leading cause of death worldwide, and the development of new therapies is urgently needed. In this study, we found that the activation of the PI3K-AKT-mTOR signaling pathway confers resistance to ferroptosis, a form of regulated necrosis driven by iron-dependent lipid peroxidation. This resistance is mediated by the activation of sterol regulatory element-binding protein 1 (SREBP1), a central transcription factor regulating lipid metabolism. We also found that SREBP1-mediated lipogenesis protects cancer cells from ferroptosis through the induction of stearoyl-CoA desaturase-1 (SCD1), a key enzyme in fatty acid desaturation. Thus, the activation of the PI3K-AKT-mTOR pathway confers resistance to ferroptosis in cancer cells, and the combination of mTORC1 inhibition with ferroptosis induction may be a promising strategy for cancer therapy. Hypertension is the most common risk factor for heart failure, and the treatment of hypertension is the cornerstone of cardiovascular disease prevention. The most common drugs for treating hypertension are the L-type Ca2+ channel blockers (LCCBs). However, the mechanisms of action of LCCBs are not fully understood. Here, we show that LCCBs activate Ca2+ signaling pathways that promote vascular remodeling. Our findings provide a mechanistic explanation for the association of LCCBs with heart failure and suggest that LCCBs should be used with caution in patients with advanced hypertension and/or cardiovascular remodeling. This study also provides a rationale for the development of new drugs that target the Ca2+ signaling pathways that are activated by LCCBs. (Show more)

The Northwest Forest Plan (NWFP) was a landmark policy that changed the way forests were managed in the Pacific Northwest. We show that the NWFP halted the decline of bird populations associated with early-seral forests, but not older forests. Our findings highlight the importance of continuing to prioritize older forests under the NWFP and the need to ensure that the recently proposed creation of early-seral ecosystems does not impede the conservation and development of older-forest structure.

We present a rational design approach, in which acylide antibiotics were screened based on computational predictions of solubility, membrane permeability, and binding affinity toward the ribosome. Deep convolutional neural networks have been successfully applied to many image-processing problems in recent works. However, the number of trainable parameters in these networks is often very large, making it difficult to train and apply the networks in practice. Here, we introduce a network architecture based on using dilated convolutions to capture features at different image scales and densely connecting all feature maps with each other. The resulting architecture is able to achieve accurate results with relatively few parameters, and consists of a single set of operations, making it easier to implement, train, and apply in practice. We compare results of the proposed network architecture with popular existing architectures for several segmentation problems, showing that the proposed architecture is able to achieve accurate results with fewer parameters, with a reduced risk of overfitting the training data.

The evolution of the Lake Malawi cichlid fish species flock is a classic example of the impact of environmental change on biological diversity. We show that the evolution of this species flock, and the diversification of the fish, was influenced by the hydroclimate of the region. The fish are endemic to the lake, and the species flock is one of the most diverse in the world. We show that the evolution of the species flock was linked to changes in the hydroclimate of the region, and that the fish were able to adapt to the changing environment.

The use of electronic devices in the hours before bedtime is widespread in the United States and around the world. This study shows that the use of an electronic device in the hours before bedtime suppresses melatonin, phase-delays the circadian clock, and reduces the amount of sleep. These effects may have important implications for health, safety, and performance.

The Younger Dryas (YDB) boundary is a key event in the history of the Earth system, and it is widely accepted that a bolide impact triggered the YDB. However, the origin of the bolide remains controversial. Here, we show that the osmium isotopic composition of magnetic grains and microspherules from the YDB sites is consistent with a terrestrial origin, and the spherules from the YDB site in Pennsylvania are likely ejecta from an impact. These results support the impact hypothesis for the YDB.

The role of CTLA-4 in the immune system is controversial, and its specific function in the development of autoimmunity is not known. Here, we show that the loss of CTLA-4 in adult mice leads to a spectrum of autoimmunity, which is not observed in congenital deficiency. This suggests that the role of CTLA-4 in the immune system is not restricted to the development of autoimmunity, but also in the control of autoimmunity.

Beetles are arguably the most speciose group of animals, but the history of beetles, including the impact of plant feeding on beetle diversification, remains poorly understood. We used a combination of genomic and fossil data to trace the evolution of beetles, revealing that the origin of Coleoptera occurred in the Carboniferous, and that plant cell wall-degrading enzymes obtained from bacteria and fungi via horizontal gene transfers may have been key to the Mesozoic diversification of herbivorous beetles. These novel genes triggered adaptive radiations of specialized herbivorous beetles, resulting in nearly half of all living beetle species.

The ability of viruses to mutate and evade the human immune system and neutralizing antibodies remains an obstacle to antiviral and vaccine development. Here, we introduce a deep learning algorithm that efficiently enhances antibody affinity to achieve broader and more potent neutralizing activity against SARS-CoV-2 variants. We demonstrate the utility of our approach on a human antibody P36-5D2, which is effective against SARS-CoV-2 Alpha, Beta, and Gamma but not Delta. We show that our approach can identify CDR changes that alleviate the impact of two Omicron mutations on the epitope. These results highlight the power of our deep learning approach in antibody optimization and its potential application to engineering other protein molecules. Our optimized antibodies can potentially be developed into antibody drug candidates for current and emerging SARS-CoV-2 variants.

The extent to which larger populations enhance cumulative cultural evolution (CCE) is a topic of great interest to evolutionary biologists, anthropologists, and technology innovators. We report a large-scale experiment (n = 543) that investigates the CCE of technology (paper planes and their flight distances) using a transmission-chain design. We find that larger populations do not enhance CCE, and that it may be only under certain specific conditions that larger population sizes enhance CCE. Our results have implications for the evolution of technology, the design of technology innovation systems, and the design of social learning environments.

Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is the most common cause of dementia and the fifth leading cause of death in the United States. The strongest genetic risk factor for AD is the apoE allele, APOE4. APOE is a large protein that is synthesized by astrocytes, a type of glial cell that is thought to play a role in AD. We show here that APOE is important for the rate of synapse pruning by astrocytes, which is a process that is thought to be important for normal brain development and function. We also show that APOE is important for the accumulation of senescent synapses in the brain, which may contribute to AD pathology. These studies reveal a novel role for APOE in regulating the rate of synapse pruning by astrocytes and suggest the hypothesis that APOE4 may contribute to AD pathology by accelerating the rate of accumulation of senescent synapses in the brain.

The Earth's inner core is a solid core that is thought to have formed by the crystallization of molten iron. However, the nucleation mechanism of the inner core is still unclear. In this study, we show that the nucleation of the body-centered cubic phase of iron is much more likely than that of the hcp phase, which is the stable phase of iron at the inner core conditions. This mechanism reduces the required undercooling of iron nucleation, which provides a key factor in solving the inner core nucleation paradox. The two-step nucleation scenario of the inner core also opens an avenue for understanding the structure and anisotropy of the present inner core. Our results provide a new perspective on the formation of the Earth's inner core. They also provide a useful reference for the study of the formation of other dense solids. (Show more)

Marijuana is the most commonly used illicit drug in the United States. Although the effects of chronic marijuana use on the brain are well known, the effects of acute marijuana use on the brain are less understood. Here, we show that the brain’s response to a drug that elevates extracellular dopamine (methylphenidate) is reduced in marijuana abusers, who also have higher levels of negative emotionality and addiction severity. These findings suggest that the brain’s reactivity to the stimulation of dopamine may contribute to the negative emotionality and addictive behaviors of marijuana abusers. These findings also highlight the need to investigate the effects of marijuana on the brain in order to develop effective treatments for marijuana abuse.

Language is a uniquely human ability, and the human brain is uniquely adapted to process language. We here show that the most powerful artificial neural networks also capture the brain’s language processing mechanisms, providing a computational link between the two. This result has implications for the nature of language in the human mind, the nature of the brain’s language machinery, and the design of artificial intelligence.

Deep learning (DL) has been a major breakthrough in machine learning, but it is still in its infancy. It is now entering scientific computing with full force. However, the stability of DL methods is a major concern, and it is not clear whether the current methods are stable. We show that there are problems in scientific computing where one can prove the existence of stable neural networks (NNs), but there does not exist any algorithm, even randomized, that can train (or compute) such a NN. This implies a classification theory describing conditions under which (stable) NNs can be computed by an algorithm. We introduce fast iterative restarted networks (FIRENETs), which we both prove and numerically verify are stable. Moreover, we prove that only O(|log (ϵ)|) layers are needed for an ϵ-accurate solution to the inverse problem. Our results provide a theoretical foundation for the stability of DL methods.

The COVID-19 pandemic is a global tragedy. It is also a case study in the limits of human cognition. The pandemic’s origin, spread, and severity are all tied to people’s inability to understand exponential growth. This inability is in turn rooted in a classic psychological experiment published 45 years ago. The experiment’s critical design flaws were not noticed at the time, and the study’s conclusion—that people are unable to understand exponential growth—was widely accepted. This article discusses the study’s flaws, the impact of these flaws on the study’s conclusion, and the implications of the study’s flaws for the study of human cognition.

Leprosy is a disease that has been with us for thousands of years, and it continues to be a major public health problem in many parts of the world. The causative agent, Mycobacterium leprae, has been studied for more than a century, and it is now clear that it is responsible for the disease. However, the pathogen has undergone extensive reductive evolution, and the genome sequence of the only cultured strain, Mycobacterium leprae, is only 1.8 Mb in size. In this paper, we report the genome sequence of a second strain, Mycobacterium lepromatosis, which is associated with a different clinical form of the disease. We find that the two strains are very similar, and we discuss the implications of these findings for the evolution of the leprosy pathogen. (PsycINFO Database Record

The dynamics of entanglement and entropy in quantum many-body systems is a central topic of current research. Here, we provide a complete description of the dynamics of entanglement in the space–time scaling limit, which is the relevant regime for the study of quantum quenches. We show that the entanglement dynamics is captured by a statistical ensemble with a nonzero thermodynamic entropy, which is the accumulated entanglement. This result is obtained by combining integrability with a quasiparticle picture of the entanglement dynamics. We check our result for the paradigmatic Heisenberg chain and discuss its implications for the dynamics of entanglement in general systems. Our work provides a framework for the study of the dynamics of entanglement in general quantum many-body systems.

The COVID-19 pandemic has claimed the lives of more than 5.2 million people worldwide. The development of a vaccine is the most effective way to control the pandemic. Here, we describe a live attenuated SARS-CoV-2 vaccine candidate, COVI-VAC, that is being developed by the University of Oxford. We show that this vaccine candidate is highly protective in a relevant hamster model. This, coupled with its large-scale manufacturing potential, supports its potential use in mass vaccination programs.

The Black Death, caused by Yersinia pestis, was one of the deadliest pandemics in human history. The disease spread rapidly through Europe, killing millions of people. The vector of the disease is still debated, with the most common hypothesis being that rats were responsible for the spread of the disease. However, we show that human fleas were the primary vector of the disease during the Second Pandemic, including the Black Death. This has important implications for the control of the disease, as it suggests that the use of rat-proofing methods was not effective in preventing the spread of the disease. Our results also suggest that the use of rats as a biological control method for plague may have been counterproductive.

The evolution of the brain is one of the most important topics in biology. It is also one of the most difficult to study because of the complexity of the brain and the difficulty of obtaining data on the number of neurons in different species. Here we use the largest dataset of its kind to reconstruct the evolution of the brain in amniotes, a group that includes birds and mammals. We show that the brain of reptiles is small relative to body size but has a low number of neurons, resulting in an average of 20 times fewer neurons than in birds and mammals of similar body size. The evolution of the brain is characterized by four major shifts in neuron–brain scaling. The most important shifts are related to the evolution of birds and mammals.

The role of TRAP1 in mitochondria has been the subject of intense investigation, but the function of TRAP1 in mitochondria of normal cells has been unclear. We have used TRAP1-null cells and transient TRAP1 silencing/overexpression to show that TRAP1 regulates a metabolic switch between oxidative phosphorylation and aerobic glycolysis in immortalized mouse fibroblasts and in human tumor cells. TRAP1-deficiency promotes an increase in mitochondrial respiration and fatty acid oxidation, and in cellular accumulation of tricarboxylic acid cycle intermediates, ATP and reactive oxygen species. At the same time, glucose metabolism is suppressed. TRAP1-deficient cells also display strikingly enhanced invasiveness. TRAP1 interaction with and regulation of mitochondrial c-Src provide a mechanistic basis for these phenotypes. Taken together with the observation that TRAP1 expression is inversely correlated with tumor grade in several cancers, these data suggest that, in some settings, this mitochondrial molecular chaperone may act as a tumor suppressor. Actin depolymerizing factor (ADF) is a protein that is involved in severing actin filaments. However, the mechanism by which it does so is not known. Here, we use single-molecule, single-filament, and filament network techniques to study the action of ADF in different mechanical situations. We find that ADF binds to filaments in a mechanical-dependent manner, and that the mechanical state of the filament network strongly influences the rate of severing. We propose a mechanochemical model that explains our results and suggests that ADF’s ability to sever filament networks is enhanced by a torque that it induces. We propose that this mechanism is critical to ADF’s function in cells.

Fructose, a common sweetener, is often used in combination with glucose in foods and beverages. This study shows that fructose relative to glucose results in greater brain activation of reward-related regions and greater hunger and desire for food. These findings suggest that fructose may be a stronger stimulus for feeding behavior than glucose. The results also suggest that the effects of fructose on brain and behavior may be mediated, at least in part, by the hormone insulin. These findings have implications for understanding the role of fructose in the development of obesity and diabetes. (PsycINFO Database Record

Madagascar is a unique island in terms of its biodiversity and its human history. The island is located ∼400 km from the east coast of Africa, but its genetic and linguistic traits are from both Southeast Asia and Eastern Africa. We used a grid-based approach to sample the genomic diversity across Madagascar and found that the population is a mixture of Bantu and Austronesian people. The settlement history of Madagascar is also debated, and we found that the population has a recent common Bantu and Austronesian ancestry. However, the distribution of African and Asian ancestry across the island reveals that the admixture was sex biased and happened heterogeneously across Madagascar, suggesting independent colonization of Madagascar from Africa and Asia rather than settlement by an already admixed population. In addition, a few centuries is sufficient to produce detectable genetic structure in human populations. This study provides a new perspective on the human history of Madagascar. It also provides a framework for the study of the human history of other islands in the Indian Ocean.

We show that people’s emotions are influenced by the emotions of others in a large social network. This finding has implications for our understanding of the spread of emotions in society, and for the design of social networks that are more positive.

Messenger RNA sequences can be modified after transcription, and these modifications can have important effects on protein synthesis. We show that the presence of a single pseudouridine (Ψ) in an mRNA codon can reduce the rate of protein synthesis and the fidelity of translation. We also show that the presence of Ψ can promote the synthesis of multiple peptides from a single mRNA sequence, and that the number of peptides produced can be increased by increasing the rate of translation. These findings suggest that the presence of Ψ in coding regions of mRNA sequences can have a modest impact on protein synthesis. This work provides a better understanding of the impact of mRNA modifications on protein synthesis and may have implications for the design of therapeutic RNA-based drugs. (Show more)

The feeling that one’s life is filled with worthwhile activities is fundamental to human flourishing and subjective well-being. Here, we show that this feeling is associated with a wide range of positive outcomes, including better health, stronger social relationships, and greater use of time. These findings have implications for the design of interventions to promote healthy aging. They also suggest that the feeling that one’s life is filled with worthwhile activities may be a key to human flourishing and longevity.

The evolution of larger body sizes in aquatic mammals is a key feature of the history of life in the water. This study shows that the evolution of an aquatic lifestyle is driving three of the four extant aquatic mammal clades toward a size attractor at ∼500 kg. The existence of this body size attractor and the relatively rapid selection toward, and limited deviation from, this attractor rule out most hypothesized drivers of size increase. These three independent body size increases and a shared aquatic optimum size are consistent with control by differences in the scaling of energetic intake and cost functions with body size between the terrestrial and aquatic realms.

Rhinovirus is the most common cause of the common cold, and the ability of this virus to replicate more efficiently at the cool temperatures of the nasal cavity than at core body temperature has important implications for the development of effective antiviral therapies. We show that rhinovirus replicates more efficiently at the cool temperatures of the nasal cavity than at core body temperature, in part, due to a less efficient antiviral defense response of infected cells at cool temperature. These findings have implications for the development of effective antiviral therapies. (PsycINFO Database Record

Bacteria use a variety of mechanisms to sense their environment, and the results of these sensing systems can be used to direct the direction of cell movement, the expression of virulence factors, and the formation of biofilms. Here we show that the opportunistic pathogen Pseudomonas aeruginosa uses the mechanical activity of its surface-adhesin pili to detect surfaces, and that this sensing system is used to regulate the expression of virulence factors and the formation of biofilms. This study provides insight into the evolution of bacterial sensing systems and the regulation of bacterial behavior. It also provides a model for how bacteria can use pili to detect surfaces and how this information can be used to regulate the expression of virulence factors and the formation of biofilms. The use of pesticides in agriculture has increased dramatically in recent decades, and the number of pesticides available to farmers is constantly growing. This study provides a comprehensive analysis of the global occurrence of pesticides in surface water and the risk of exceeding the legally accepted regulatory threshold levels. We show that the biological integrity of global water resources is at a substantial risk, and that the use of pesticides in agriculture is one of the main drivers of the decline of aquatic biodiversity.

The COVID-19 pandemic has had a profound impact on human health and the global economy. The virus has also spread to animals, including wildlife, and the potential for spillback to humans is a major concern. Here, we report the detection of SARS-CoV-2 in white-tailed deer, a species of conservation concern in Iowa. We also show that SARS-CoV-2 is circulating in deer during the winter months, when human cases are low. These findings have important implications for the long-term persistence of the pandemic and the need for a proactive “One Health” approach to understand the ecology, molecular evolution, and dissemination of SARS-CoV-2. Our study highlights the need for a better understanding of the role of wildlife in the pandemic and the need for a coordinated global response.

The proliferation of large dams in the developing world is a major concern for the environment, people, and the climate. This paper examines the history of the development of hydropower and the proliferation of large dams in the developing world. It also examines the challenges of incorporating climate change into the decision-making process of whether to build a dam. We also examine the overestimation of benefits and underestimation of costs along with changes that are needed to address the legitimate social and environmental concerns of people living in areas where dams are planned. Finally, we propose innovative solutions that can move hydropower toward sustainable practices together with solar, wind, and other renewable sources.

Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is the most common cause of dementia, and the lack of effective treatments has led to a worldwide search for new therapies. The disease is thought to be caused by the accumulation of amyloid-β (Aβ) and tau proteins, which are deposited in the brain and are thought to trigger an immune response. Here, we show that neurons, which are the primary cell type in the brain, are also involved in the immune response. We demonstrate that neurons are the source of cytokines that trigger the immune response in the brain, and that this response is more likely to occur in regions of the brain that are vulnerable to AD. Our findings may lead to the development of new therapies for AD. (PsycINFO Database Record

The use of animals for economic purposes is one of the most important developments in human history. The earliest evidence for the economic exploitation of animals is found in the archaeological record of the Near East, where the exploitation of sheep and goats is documented in the fourth millennium B.C.E. The question of when and where chickens were first used for economic purposes remains unresolved. We present evidence from the Hellenistic site of Maresha, Israel, that chickens were first used for economic purposes in the second millennium B.C.E. This is the earliest known evidence for the economic exploitation of chickens in the world.

Dinucleoside tetraphosphates, which are abundant in response to stress, have been shown to function as precursors to RNA caps. In this study, we show that the decapping enzyme responsible for removing those caps, in bacteria that use them, is inactivated by the conditions that enable their accumulation. We also show that, in the absence of ApaH, the enzyme responsible for removing the caps, RppH, becomes the predominant decapping enzyme, and that it prefers capped substrates as substrates over their counterparts that are triphosphorylated or diphosphorylated. These findings have implications for the regulation of gene expression during stress, as well as for the development of strategies to manipulate the expression of specific genes in bacteria. (Show more)

Sepsis is a life-threatening condition that is associated with a high mortality rate. The immune system is the main target of sepsis, and the main mechanism of immune dysfunction is the expansion of immunosuppressive cells, such as myeloid-derived suppressor cells and regulatory T cells. We demonstrated that citrulline, a nonessential amino acid, can be used as a therapeutic strategy to restore the immune system in sepsis. This study provides evidence for developing citrulline-based clinical studies in sepsis. This strategy could be used as a new treatment for sepsis in the future.

The biomass of the biosphere is the sum of the masses of all the organisms that inhabit the planet. It is a key parameter for understanding the structure and dynamics of the biosphere. However, a global, quantitative view of how the biomass of different taxa compare with one another is still lacking. Here, we assemble the overall biomass composition of the biosphere, establishing a census of the ≈550 Gt C of biomass distributed among all of the kingdoms of life. We show that the biomass of humans is an order of magnitude higher than that of all wild mammals combined, and that the global marine biomass pyramid contains more consumers than producers. Our analysis highlights the importance of the global marine biomass for the functioning of the biosphere. Finally, we highlight the historical impact of humanity on the global biomass of prominent taxa, including mammals, fish, and plants. Our results provide a global view of the biomass of the biosphere and its distribution among the kingdoms of life. They are a valuable resource for future studies on the structure and dynamics of the biosphere.

Self-organized criticality (SOC) is a fascinating phenomenon in nature and in physics, where a system evolves in time in a way that the rate of change of the system’s state is proportional to the current state of the system. SOC systems are characterized by the fact that the rate of change of the system’s state is close to zero, and the system’s state changes unpredictably from time to time. In this paper, we report on our discovery of a tropical model with self-organized criticality (SOC) behavior. Our model is continuous, in contrast to all known models of SOC, and is a certain scaling limit of the sandpile model, the first and archetypical model of SOC. We describe how our model is related to pattern formation and proportional growth phenomena and discuss the dichotomy between continuous and discrete models in several contexts. Our aim in this context is to present an idealized tropical toy model, requiring further investigation.

Diamond is a unique material with a wide bandgap, high hardness, and high thermal conductivity. It is widely used in electronics, optics, and photonics. However, it is brittle and has a low fracture toughness. Therefore, it is desirable to control its mechanical properties, such as its elastic modulus and strength, to improve its performance in applications. Here, we show that diamond can be metallized, solely under mechanical strain without phonon instability, and that its electronic bandgap can be fully closed. These findings offer opportunities for tailoring properties of diamond via strain engineering for electronic, photonic, and quantum applications. They also provide insights into the mechanism of metallization and the origin of the bandgap closure in diamond. This work is expected to stimulate further experimental and theoretical studies. (Show more)

The study of plant immunity has been revolutionized by the development of CRISPR/Cas9 technology. However, the mechanisms of action of many of the plant immune effectors are unknown. Here, we report the structural and functional characterization of a plant immune effector, NCR044, which is a member of a large family of cysteine-rich peptides. We show that this peptide is a potent fungicide and that it binds to multiple bioactive phosphoinositides in vitro. We also show that it binds to the fungal cell wall and induces membrane permeabilization and cell death in germlings of plant fungal pathogens. This work provides insights into the structural and functional features of this class of peptides and paves the way for future development of this class of peptides as a spray-on fungistat/fungicide. (Show more)

The male–female reproductive interface is the site of the most intimate interactions between the sexes. In this study, we provide a comprehensive characterization of the posttesticular life history of the Drosophila sperm proteome. We show that the sperm proteome undergoes substantial changes after being transferred to the female reproductive tract. We also show that the female reproductive tract contributes to the sperm proteome, and that these contributions are enriched for proteins involved in energy metabolism. These findings provide a comprehensive characterization of the posttesticular life history of the sperm proteome and expand our understanding of the critical process of sperm–female reproductive tract interactions. (Show more)

Von Willebrand factor (VWF) is a large protein that binds to platelets, in part, by binding to glycoprotein Ibα (GPIbα) on the surface of platelets. The binding reaction is triggered, in part, by alterations in flow. We show that force application switches VWF to a second state with faster on-rate, providing a mechanism for activating VWF binding to platelets. This mechanism is important for understanding the pathophysiology of von Willebrand disease, a disorder of VWF function. The results also suggest that the conversion of single molecule kon (s−1) to bulk phase kon (s−1M−1) and the kon and koff values extrapolated to zero force for the low-force pathways show remarkably good agreement with bulk-phase measurements. This is a significant result for the field. (Show more)

The human microbiome is a complex ecosystem of bacteria that has been the subject of intense study for the last decade. However, the viral component of the microbiome has been more difficult to study, and the lack of a comprehensive database has hindered the ability to understand the role of viruses in human health. This study provides a resource for the human virome, and we find that viruses are associated with a wide range of diseases. This resource will enable future studies to investigate the role of viruses in health and disease.

Aerosol–cloud interaction (ACI) is one of the most important processes in the climate system. However, ACI is difficult to be well represented in current climate models. This is due to the complexity of ACI and the lack of observational capability. Here, we introduce a new technique, the dual-field-of-view high-spectral-resolution lidar (HSRL), to investigate ACI. The HSRL is capable of simultaneously profiling aerosol and water cloud properties, especially water cloud microphysical properties. We demonstrate the scientific potential of the HSRL to contribute to ACI investigations. The observations obtained from the HSRL constitute substantial and significant additions to understanding ACI process. This technique is expected to represent a significant step forward in characterizing ACI. This work will help us to understand the role of aerosols in the climate system. It will also help us to improve climate models. This will, in turn, help us to better predict the future climate.

The temperature of Earth’s surface has been a topic of great interest for many years. The temperature of the surface of the Earth is important for the survival of life on the planet, and it is also important for the interpretation of the history of the Earth. This study provides a new method for determining the temperature of the Earth’s surface in the past, based on the thermostability of enzymes reconstructed from ancient organisms.

Ion channels are the main regulators of ion flow in the body. They are also the main targets of drugs. Ion channels are classified into three types, depending on the number of pore gates. The large-conductance calcium-activated potassium (BK) channel is a type-3 channel, which has no classic activation gate and shows no C-type inactivation. We found that the BK channel’s C-type inactivation is state-dependent, and that its extents and rates inversely correlate with channel-open probability. We propose that the BK channel’s normal closing may represent an early conformational stage of C-type inactivation. This study provides a new perspective on the regulation of ion channels. (Show more)

Malaria is one of the most devastating diseases in the world, with an estimated 207 million cases and 435,000 deaths in 2015. The parasite exploits the host cell to facilitate entry into the human body, but the mechanism of invasion is poorly understood. Here, we show that the malaria parasite alters the physical properties of the host cell, increasing the tension of the cytoskeleton and reducing the bending rigidity of the membrane, which leads to an increase in invasion efficiency. This work provides a new perspective on the invasion process and opens up the possibility of targeting the physical properties of the host cell to reduce the severity of malaria. (Show more)

Diamond is a unique material with a wide bandgap, high hardness, and high thermal conductivity. It is widely used in electronics, optics, and photonics. However, it is brittle and has a low fracture toughness. Therefore, it is desirable to control its mechanical properties, such as its elastic modulus and strength, to improve its performance in applications. Here, we show that diamond can be metallized, solely under mechanical strain without phonon instability, and that its electronic bandgap can be fully closed. These findings offer opportunities for tailoring properties of diamond via strain engineering for electronic, photonic, and quantum applications. They also provide insights into the mechanism of metallization and the role of strain in the phase transition from diamond to graphite. This work is expected to promote the development of diamond-based applications. (Show more)

The impact of ambient humidity on the severity of influenza virus infection remains unclear. Here, we show that mice housed in low humidity are more susceptible to severe disease following influenza virus infection. We find that low humidity impairs mucociliary clearance, innate antiviral defense, and tissue repair. Moreover, disease exacerbated by low humidity was ameliorated in mice lacking the key effector of caspase-1/11, independent of viral burden. These results indicate that exposure to dry air impairs host defense against influenza infection, reduces tissue repair, and inflicts caspase-dependent disease pathology. Our findings provide insights into the role of ambient humidity in the severity of influenza virus infection and may help to develop strategies to mitigate the impact of influenza virus outbreaks. (Show more)

The brain is thought to build syntactic structures in a left-corner fashion, starting with the simplest elements and gradually adding more complex ones. This process is thought to be driven by a merge operation, which combines two words or phrases into a single one. We show that this operation is implemented by a neural mechanism that is present in multiple areas of the brain, including the superior temporal and inferior frontal regions, and that it is necessary for the construction of multiword phrases. Our results provide initial evidence for the neurophysiological reality of the merge operation and suggest that the brain builds syntactic structures in a left-corner fashion.

The canonical Wnt pathway is a major regulator of development and homeostasis. It is also a target of cancer, and its regulation is a focus of cancer research. We show here that the two forms of Axin, which are similar at the protein level, are regulated differently at the transcriptional and proteostatic level. This differential regulation may be used to control the responsiveness of the pathway in different tissues.

The lateral hypothalamus (LH) is a key region of the brain that controls feeding. Here we describe a circuit that may promote overeating and contribute to obesity. This circuit is located in the LH, where it projects to the ventral tegmental area and the substantia nigra, and then to the locus coeruleus and peri-lateral hypothalamic area. This circuit is critical for the rapid vigorous eating induced by stimulation of LH neurons. We show that this circuit is not involved in the regulation of hunger or satiety, suggesting that it may be a target for therapeutic intervention in obesity.

Nitrogen is the most limiting nutrient for plant growth, and the ability to control the nitrogen-fixing bacteria that provide it is a key component of sustainable agriculture. Here, we demonstrate the development of a synthetic plant-controlled nitrogen-fixing symbiosis in which the bacteria fix nitrogen only when in contact with the desired host plant. This work represents a key milestone toward the development of a synthetic plant-controlled symbiosis in which the bacteria fix nitrogen only when in contact with the desired host plant and are prevented from interaction with nontarget plant species. This work also provides a proof of concept for the use of rhizopine, a bacterial signal, as a tool for the control of gene expression in a bacterial symbiont. This work is expected to have a significant impact on the field of plant–microbe interactions and on the field of synthetic biology. (Show more)

The Amazon is the world’s most important tropical forest, and its future is critical to the global environment and economy. Despite substantial investments in remote-sensed forest monitoring, the Amazon is still losing forest at an alarming rate. We study a community-based monitoring program that was designed to improve the effectiveness of remote-sensed alerts and to provide an incentive for communities to protect their forests. We find that the program reduced deforestation in the communities that participated, but the estimated effects are imprecise. Our findings suggest that externally facilitated community-based monitoring protocols that combine remote-sensed early deforestation alerts with training and incentives for monitors could contribute to sustainable forest management.

Hearing is a fundamental sense of many animals, including all mammals, birds, some reptiles, amphibians, fish, and arthropods. The auditory organs of these animals are extremely diverse in anatomy after hundreds of millions of years of evolution, yet all are made up of cellular tissue and are morphologically part of the body of the animal. Here, we show that hearing in the orb-weaving spider Larinioides sclopetarius is not constrained by the organism’s body but is outsourced to its extended phenotype, the proteinaceous, self-manufactured orb web.

The health and climate impacts of air pollution and greenhouse gases are difficult to disentangle. We show that the removal of fossil-fuel-related emissions and anthropogenic aerosols, which are both major contributors to the global warming, can save millions of lives and restore rainfall patterns. This would also limit the global warming to 2 °C. However, the health benefits are much larger than the climate benefits, indicating that the climate benefits are not the main reason for the phaseout of fossil fuels.

COVID-19 is a global pandemic that has killed over 500,000 people in the United States alone. The lack of a vaccine has been a major obstacle to containing the pandemic. Here we report the design and characterization of a SARS-CoV-2 RBD protein that is well-suited for large-scale production and elicits high-affinity antibodies. This protein can be used to generate vaccines and other products, such as diagnostic tests. This engineered protein can be used to generate vaccines and other products, such as diagnostic tests.

The development of the neural crest, a transient embryonic cell population, is essential for the formation of many tissues and organs. In the last years, we have identified a group of proteins that are involved in the regulation of this process. These proteins are secreted and have a tyrosine kinase domain. We show here that these proteins are ligands for the ALK family of receptors and that they are involved in the development of the pigment cells of the zebrafish. Our results provide evidence for the involvement of this receptor family in the regulation of the development of this cell population. This is important for understanding the role of these receptors in human development.

The emergence of plague, the most devastating infectious disease in human history, is a mystery that has been the subject of intense research for centuries. The identification of ancient Yersinia pestis genomes has provided a glimpse into the pathogen’s early evolution and ecology, but the number of genomes available to date has been too small to explore its diversity during this critical period of development. Here, we present 17 Y. pestis genomes from 5,000 to 2,500 y BP, which allowed us to explore correlations between temporal, geographical, and genetic distance. Our results suggest a nonflea-adapted and potentially extinct single lineage that persisted over millennia without significant parallel diversification, accompanied by rapid dispersal across continents throughout this period. Together, these data reveal the dynamic nature of plague’s formative years in terms of its early evolution and ecology. This work provides a unique perspective on the history of plague and its impact on human populations. (Show more)

This work examined the role of the culturally endorsed form of masculinity—hegemonic masculinity (HM)—in men’s and women’s support for Donald Trump in the 2016 presidential election and Joe Biden in the 2020 presidential election. Consistent with our theoretical backdrop, HM predicted men’s and women’s support for Trump, over and above political party affiliation, gender, race, and education. These effects held when controlling for respondents’ trust in the government, in contrast to a populist explanation of support for Trump. HM was associated with less trust in the government, more sexism, more racism, and more xenophobia but continued to predict unique variance in evaluations of Trump when controlling for each of these factors. The findings highlight the importance of psychological examinations of masculinity as a cultural ideology to understand how men’s and women’s endorsement of HM legitimizes patriarchal dominance and reinforces gender, race, and class-based hierarchies via candidate support. The agricultural management of grasslands and croplands has been shown to affect the amount and distribution of soil organic carbon (SOC) in the United States and worldwide. However, the effects of these management practices on SOC storage and distribution in the United States are not well understood. We show that soil health management practices, such as reduced tillage, diversified crop rotations, and manure addition, can increase SOC storage and distribution in the mineral soil, but the effects of these practices on SOC storage in the soil organic matter fraction are highly dependent on the management of the perennial grasslands. These results highlight the importance of well-managed grasslands in climate-smart agriculture. Our findings have implications for the management of agricultural lands in the United States and worldwide.

The COVID-19 pandemic has highlighted the vulnerability of humans to zoonotic viral threats. We developed a framework to identify and prioritize wildlife viruses with the greatest potential to spillover to humans. We used this framework to identify the top 12 wildlife viruses with the greatest spillover potential, which included SARS-CoV-2. We created a web tool, SpillOver, that allows users to explore the results and to search for viruses of interest. SpillOver is a living database that can be refined over time to continue to improve the quality and public availability of information on viral threats to human health. SpillOver is a valuable resource for policy makers and health scientists to inform research and public health interventions for prevention and rapid control of disease outbreaks.

Nectar is the main reward that plants offer to pollinators for visitation. One of the main colors of nectar is red, which is thought to be a visual attractant for pollinators. We show that the red color of nectar in Nesocodon mauritianus is derived from a previously undescribed alkaloid, nesocodin. We identify three enzymes that are either necessary or sufficient for the production of this pigment. We also identify nesocodin in the red nectar of two other vertebrate-visited plants, Jaltomata herrerae and Nesocodon, and provide molecular evidence for convergent evolution of this trait. This work provides a better understanding of the evolution of this type of adaptation and the role of alkaloids in plant–pollinator interactions. It also provides a new source of natural colorants. (Show more)

The genetic history of Europe during the period of the Migration Period (5th–7th centuries AD) is poorly understood. Here we present a genome-wide analysis of a group of individuals from Bavaria, Germany, who died mostly between 480 and 620 AD. Our data indicate that the genetic ancestry of men is mostly consistent with that of modern northern and central Europeans, but that women exhibit a very high genetic heterogeneity. This includes signals of genetic ancestry ranging from western Europe to East Asia. We also show that many alleles associated with recent positive selection were already at modern-like frequencies in European populations ∼1,500 years ago. Our results indicate that complex demographic processes during the Early Medieval period may have contributed in an unexpected way to shape the modern European genetic landscape. This study provides a unique opportunity to understand the genetic history of Europe during a period of great cultural change.

Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV) is a zoonotic pathogen that causes ∼36% fatality in infected patients. To understand how bat coronaviruses transmit to humans, we investigated the receptor usage and cell entry activity of the virus-surface spike proteins of two bat coronaviruses, HKU4 and HKU5. We found that dipeptidyl peptidase 4 (DPP4), the receptor for MERS-CoV, is also the receptor for HKU4, but not HKU5. Despite sharing a common receptor, MERS-CoV and HKU4 spikes demonstrated functional differences. These results establish DPP4 as a functional receptor for HKU4 and host cellular proteases as a host range determinant for HKU4. They also suggest that DPP4-recognizing bat coronaviruses threaten human health because of their spikes’ capability to adapt to human cells for cross-species transmissions. Our findings are important for understanding the origin and evolution of MERS-CoV and for developing strategies to prevent future zoonotic outbreaks. (Show more)

The global pandemic of COVID-19 has highlighted the need for rapid, accurate, and scalable pathogen surveillance. Here, we describe the use of metagenomic next-generation sequencing (mNGS) to detect a variety of vector-borne, zoonotic, and emerging pathogens in a periurban population in Cambodia. We demonstrate that mNGS can be used to detect undifferentiated febrile illness, and that the detection of vector-borne pathogens is associated with the risk of undifferentiated febrile illness. This study highlights the potential of mNGS to detect undifferentiated febrile illness, and the detection of vector-borne pathogens, which are associated with the risk of undifferentiated febrile illness. This study also highlights the need for ongoing pathogen surveillance to better understand the breadth of endemic, zoonotic, or emerging pathogens.
