The lagging strand of the double helix is replicated by a single DNA polymerase, pol δ, in a processive, but unstable, complex with the sliding clamp, proliferating cell nuclear antigen (PCNA). This study provides a detailed analysis of the stability and processivity of the pol δ holoenzyme. The results indicate that the human pol δ holoenzyme is more stable than previously thought and that it dissociates from PCNA more rapidly than in S. cerevisiae. These findings have implications for the replication of the lagging strand in humans and the design of new therapeutics.

The origin of life is one of the most important and enigmatic problems in science. In this paper, we describe the first experimental demonstration of the replication of genetic information in the absence of proteins. This work is important because it provides a means to study the origin of life in the laboratory, and because it may lead to the development of synthetic life forms.

We introduce a computer vision method to measure changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods from time-series street-level imagery. We find that three factors predict neighborhood improvement: (i) the density of college-educated adults, (ii) the initial appearance of the neighborhood, and (iii) the proximity of the neighborhood to other attractive neighborhoods. Together, these results provide support for three classical theories of urban change and illustrate the value of using computer vision methods and street-level imagery to understand the physical dynamics of cities. Our results also suggest that the physical appearance of neighborhoods is a key factor in the distribution of economic opportunity and that the physical environment may be a key determinant of the success of urban policy.

The treatment of severe and critical COVID-19 patients is still a challenge. In this study, we found that tocilizumab, which targets the IL-6 pathways, is effective in the treatment of severe and critical COVID-19 patients. The results of this study provide a new idea for the treatment of severe and critical COVID-19 patients.

Copper homeostasis is essential for the survival of fungi, and the mechanisms by which fungi maintain copper pools are well established. In this study, we demonstrate that the xanthocillin biosynthetic gene cluster in Aspergillus fumigatus binds copper and has a role in copper homeostasis. We also show that the xan BGC isocyanide products have antimicrobial properties and that copper is a critical component of this activity. These findings suggest that the xan BGC is a source of fungal natural products that have a role in copper homeostasis and the regulation of interactions with competing microbes. This study provides insight into the role of fungal natural products in the regulation of metal homeostasis and the interaction of fungi with their environment. (Show more)

The presence of tridymite in a Martian mudstone is significant because it is a high-pressure (<1,000 MPa) <870 °C polymorph of SiO2, which is the most common polymorph in the crust of the terrestrial planets. The presence of tridymite in a Martian mudstone is also significant because it is a product of high-temperature, high-pressure conditions, which are not expected in the crust of the terrestrial planets.

Frost damage is a major threat to agriculture, forestry, and animal husbandry, and the geographic distribution of frost events is changing in response to climate warming. We show that the geographic distribution of frost damage is changing in response to climate warming, and that the rate of change is different in different regions. Our findings can help decision-makers to adapt to the changing spring-frost risk.

Th17 cells are a major component of the inflammatory response in certain types of inflammatory bowel disease. However, the functional significance of this response is unclear. Here we show that Th17 cells are required for the development of colitis, but that this requirement is contingent on the development of Th1-like cells. These results suggest that Th17 cells are important for the initiation of disease, but that the development of Th1-like cells is required for the maintenance of disease. This model may be relevant to the development of new therapies for inflammatory bowel disease.

Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is a devastating neurodegenerative disease with no cure. The disease is caused by degeneration of motor neurons, which control voluntary muscle movement. The disease is caused by mutations in genes encoding proteins involved in the regulation of protein homeostasis, and the disease is associated with toxic protein aggregates. We now report a method to rapidly and easily produce motor neuron-like cells from living ALS patients, which can be used to study the disease and to screen for therapeutics. This method will enable the study of the disease in large numbers and will facilitate the development of new therapies.

The ability of pathogens to influence the behavior of their vectors is a key factor in the transmission of infectious diseases. Here, we show that a human pathogen, Anaplasma phagocytophilum, alters the microbiota of the vector tick, Ixodes scapularis, to more efficiently infect the tick. We demonstrate that the pathogen induces the tick to produce an antifreeze glycoprotein, which alters the composition of the tick gut microbiota. This, in turn, alters the integrity of the peritrophic matrix and gut barrier, which are critical obstacles for the pathogen to colonize the tick. These findings provide insight into the mechanisms by which pathogens influence the behavior of their vectors. (Show more)

Birds with a short tail are a key component of the modern avian bauplan, but the origin of this important feature is poorly understood. Here, we describe a basal member of the group of birds with a short tail, Jinguofortis perplexus, and show that it represents the second earliest diverging group of the Pygostylia. The discovery of Jinguofortis increases our understanding of the evolution of the avian tail and the mosaic nature of morphological change in early birds.

The climate system is very complex, and it is difficult to understand the climate system without understanding the interactions between the different components of the system. This is especially true for the climate system, which is a coupled system. In this paper, we show that the interactions between the different components of the climate system are more complex than previously thought.

Vertebrates have a variety of colors, from red to blue, and many of them are able to change their color. This phenomenon is called color polymorphism. In this study, we show that the occurrence of blue-green color in vertebrates has evolved multiple times during their evolutionary history, and that the mechanism of color change is the same—the presence of a class of proteins that bind biliverdin. We describe these proteins, hereafter named biliverdin-binding serpins, and show that they are most similar to human alpha-1-antitrypsin, but with a remarkable functional diversification. Our results present molecular and functional evidence of recurrent evolution of color polymorphism, describe a biliverdin-binding protein in vertebrates, and introduce a function for a member of the serpin superfamily, the largest and most ubiquitous group of protease inhibitors. We believe that our findings will be of interest to a broad audience of biologists.

Breast cancer is the most common cancer in women worldwide, and the leading cause of cancer death in women. Breast cancer stem cells (BCSCs) are responsible for the initiation and maintenance of the disease. We show that hypoxia induces expression of AlkB homolog 5 (ALKBH5), an m6A demethylase, which in turn increases the expression of NANOG, a gene that encodes a pluripotency factor. NANOG is methylated at an m6A residue in its 3′-UTR, which is demethylated by ALKBH5. ALKBH5 expression is increased by hypoxia, and hypoxia induces the expression of ALKBH5 and NANOG in breast cancer cells. Thus, ALKBH5 mediates the induction of BCSCs in the hypoxic tumor microenvironment. Our findings may lead to the development of new strategies for the treatment of breast cancer. (Show more)

The use of fetal animal skins in the production of parchment is a long-standing controversy in codicology. The term “uterine vellum” is often used to describe this practice, but the source of the skins has been unclear. Here, we report a simple and objective method for identifying the animal origin of parchment. We found no evidence for the use of unexpected animals, but we did identify the use of more than one mammal species in a single manuscript, consistent with the local availability of hides. These results suggest that the production of parchment was not dependent on the use of abortive or newborn animals with ultrathin skins. Instead, the production process allowed the skins of maturing animals of several species to be rendered into vellum of equal quality and fineness. This method could be used to identify the source of parchment in the future.

The Permian-Triassic extinction is the most severe loss of marine and terrestrial biota in the last 542 My. The age model for this event is critical to understanding its cause and the dynamics of extinction and recovery. We present a new age model for the extinction based on U-Pb dates from five volcanic ash beds. The extinction occurred between 251.941 ± 0.037 and 251.880 ± 0.031 Mya, an interval of 60 ± 48 ka. The carbon cycle was highly volatile during the extinction, and the recovery was slow. These results provide a new benchmark for evaluating the plausibility of trigger and kill mechanisms. (Show more)

Inflammatory bowel disease (IBD) is a group of chronic inflammatory diseases of the gastrointestinal tract, which is characterized by the excessive activation of the immune system. IBD is a major health problem, and the current treatment is limited. In this study, we found that retinoic acid-related orphan receptor α (RORα) is crucial for maintaining intestinal homeostasis by attenuating nuclear factor κB (NF-κB) transcriptional activity. We further found that RORα/HDAC3-mediated NF-κB signaling controls the balance of inflammatory responses. Our study provides a potential therapeutic target for IBD. This study also provides a new perspective for the treatment of IBD. (Show more)

The spike glycoprotein of SARS-CoV-2 is the primary target for the development of vaccines and therapeutics. We have determined the structure of the spike glycoprotein in complex with the receptor-binding domain of the ACE2 receptor, and we show that the D614G mutation in the spike protein is associated with a more open conformation of the spike protein. This may facilitate binding to the receptor and the subsequent structural rearrangements required for viral membrane fusion. Our results provide insights into the mechanism of action of the D614G mutation and may help to inform the development of vaccines and therapeutics. (Show more)

We consider repeated games with Borel-measurable payoffs, i.e., when the payoffs depend on what happens in the long run. We show that every repeated game with Borel-measurable payoffs admits an ε-equilibrium, for every ε>0, provided that the set of players is finite or countably infinite and the action sets are finite. The proof relies on techniques from stochastic games and from alternating-move games with Borel-measurable payoffs.

COVID-19 has resulted in a staggering death toll in the United States, and Black and Latino Americans have experienced a disproportionate burden of COVID-19 morbidity and mortality. We estimate the impact of COVID-19 on life expectancy in the United States in 2020, by race and ethnicity, and project the impact of COVID-19 on life expectancy in the United States in 2020, by race and ethnicity. Our projections imply an increase in the Black−White life expectancy gap of nearly 40%, and a reduction in the Latino−White life expectancy gap of more than 3 y. These projections have important implications for the future of the United States, and for the health of the most vulnerable populations.

The chemical properties of atoms are the basis of chemistry, and they are the starting point for the development of chemical models and theories. In this work, we show that the chemical properties of atoms, such as electronegativity and chemical hardness, decrease with pressure, and we propose a new way of thinking about the chemical properties of atoms. We show that the chemical properties of atoms can be used to predict and explain the behavior of chemical compounds under pressure. This work is a step forward in the development of a new chemical theory.

Climate change is expected to increase the frequency and severity of wildfires, which can alter the carbon cycle. However, the magnitude of this effect is uncertain because of the complexity of the interactions between fire, climate, and the carbon cycle. We show that human ignitions and fire suppression can have a large influence on the future fire regime, and that this can have a significant impact on the carbon cycle. Our results suggest that climate change may be slowing the rate of warming, but that this effect is likely to be small compared with the impact of human ignitions and fire suppression.

The gut microbiota of animals is a major contributor to host health, but the mechanisms by which the host regulates the composition of this community are poorly understood. Here, we show that the provision of a single glycan, chitin, by a host to its symbiotic bacteria is a mechanism for the host to control the composition of the microbiota and the health of the symbiosis.

Text data are ubiquitous, and the need to identify latent patterns in them is growing. We introduce a method to identify topics in a corpus and represent documents as topic sequences. We draw on advances in theoretical machine learning to integrate topic modeling and word embedding, capitalizing on their distinct capabilities. Our method is motivated by the need to understand the gendered nature of violent death narratives in the US National Violent Death Reporting System. Our method offers a flexible and broadly applicable approach to model topics in text data. We expect it to be useful in many domains, including social media, news, and medical records. We hope it will inspire further research on the gendered nature of topics in text.

The Black Death, the deadliest epidemic in human history, is often understood as the consequence of a single introduction of Yersinia pestis into Europe. However, the timing of the first plague outbreaks in Europe is not well known. We show that the climate conditions in Asia, where the bacterium originated, were favorable for its reintroduction into Europe, with a delay of 15 ± 1 y. Our results suggest that the Black Death was the result of repeated introductions of the bacterium into European harbors, which were then sustained by the local rodent population.

Asteroids are a group of marine invertebrates that are of economic and ecological importance. In the last 2 y, a disease has caused the mass mortality of at least 20 species of asteroids along the Pacific Coast of North America. We show that the disease is caused by a virus and that it is associated with rapid tissue degradation. The virus is likely to be spread by the movement of infected asteroids. This study provides evidence for a disease agent and a mechanism for its spread, which will help to understand the dynamics of this outbreak and to prevent its spread.

Acute myeloid leukemia (AML) is the most common form of leukemia and is associated with a poor survival rate. There is an urgent need for novel and more efficient therapies, ideally targeting AML stem cells that are essential for maintaining the disease. Here, we show that monoclonal antibodies targeting the IL1 receptor accessory protein (IL1RAP) have strong antileukemic effects in xenograft models of human AML. We demonstrate that effector-cell–mediated killing is essential for the observed therapeutic effects and that natural killer cells constitute a critical human effector cell type. We also show that an IL1RAP-targeting antibody capable of blocking IL-1 signaling can suppress the proliferation of primary human AML cells. These results provide important evidence in support of IL1RAP as a target for antibody-based treatment of AML. Furthermore, the results suggest that IL1RAP can be efficiently targeted with an anti-IL1RAP antibody capable of both achieving antibody-dependent cellular cytotoxicity and blocking of IL-1 signaling as modes of action. Thus, our results provide important insights into the biology of AML and may lead to the development of new and more efficient therapies for this disease.

Madagascar is a unique island in terms of its biodiversity and its human history. The island is located ∼400 km from the east coast of Africa, but its genetic and linguistic diversity is from both Southeast Asia and Eastern Africa. We used a grid-based approach to sample the genomic diversity across Madagascar and found that the population is a mixture of Bantu and Austronesian populations, with a limited contribution from Europe and the Middle East. The distribution of African and Asian ancestry across the island reveals that the admixture was sex biased and happened heterogeneously across Madagascar, suggesting independent colonization of Madagascar from Africa and Asia rather than settlement by an already admixed population. In addition, a few centuries is sufficient to produce detectable genetic structure in human populations. These results provide insights into the human history of Madagascar and the processes that shaped the island’s population. They also provide a framework for the study of the human history of other islands.

Bacteria have evolved small RNAs (sRNAs) to regulate numerous biological processes and stress responses. While sRNAs generally are considered to be “noncoding,” a few have been found to also encode a small protein. Here we describe one such dual-function RNA that modulates carbon utilization in Escherichia coli. The 164-nucleotide RNA was previously shown to encode a 28-amino acid protein (denoted AzuC). We discovered the membrane-associated AzuC protein interacts with aerobic glycerol-3-phosphate dehydrogenase (denoted GlpD) and increases dehydrogenase activity. We also found that the RNA that encodes AzuC interferes with the ability of the RNA to repress carbon utilization genes. These results demonstrate that the translation and base-pairing functions of the RNA compete. This is an example of a dual-function RNA that has been overlooked in the past. We believe that this work will lead to a better understanding of the evolution of dual-function RNAs and their role in bacterial physiology. (Show more)

The ability of viruses to mutate and evade the human immune system and neutralizing antibodies remains an obstacle to antiviral and vaccine development. Here, we introduce a deep learning algorithm that efficiently enhances antibody affinity to achieve broader and more potent neutralizing activity against SARS-CoV-2 variants. We demonstrate the utility of our approach on a human antibody P36-5D2, which is effective against SARS-CoV-2 Alpha, Beta, and Gamma but not Delta. We show that our approach can identify CDR changes that alleviate the impact of two Omicron mutations on the epitope. These results highlight the power of our deep learning approach in antibody optimization and its potential application to engineering other protein molecules. Our optimized antibodies can potentially be developed into antibody drug candidates for current and emerging SARS-CoV-2 variants.

Crop experts are the primary source of information on the status of crops in the field. However, their assessments are subjective and often not available in a form that can be used for quantitative analysis. We show how to transform the original qualitative data into a continuous, probabilistic variable better suited to quantitative analysis. We demonstrate that the resulting Crop Condition Index is able to provide earlier and more precise predictions of crop yields than official USDA forecasts released midseason. The proposed methodology can be used to monitor crop status and provide early warnings of crop anomalies, and can be easily extended to other crops and countries. The proposed methodology can be used to monitor crop status and provide early warnings of crop anomalies, and can be easily extended to other crops and countries.

Language is a highly complex system that involves the integration of information over time. Here we propose a mechanism for memory in the brain that is based on the adaptive changes in the firing rate of neurons. This mechanism is sensitive to context and serial order, and it can be used to bind information over time. We show that this mechanism is sensitive to context and serial order, and it can be used to bind information over time. This work provides a step toward a computational neurobiology of language.

The soil is the largest terrestrial carbon pool, and its response to climate change is of great interest to the scientific community and the general public. However, the response of soil respiration to climate change remains unclear, with some studies showing increases and others showing no change. We provide a synthesis of the largest global dataset to date of soil respiration, moisture, and temperature measurements, totaling >3,800 observations representing 27 temperature manipulation studies, spanning nine biomes and over 2 decades of warming. Our analysis provides limited evidence of acclimation of soil respiration to experimental warming in several major biome types, contrary to the results from multiple single-site studies. Our results add a unique cross-biome perspective on the temperature response of soil respiration, information critical to improving our mechanistic understanding of how soil carbon dynamics change with climatic warming.

The transition from autotrophy to a nonphotosynthetic parasitic lifestyle is one of the most important events in the history of life. It is associated with the loss of photosynthesis and the acquisition of a new lifestyle, which is characterized by the parasite’s dependence on a host to fulfill its life cycle. Here, we show that the transition to a parasitic lifestyle relaxes functional constraints on plastid genes in a stepwise manner. Our findings have implications for the evolution of the plastid genome, which is the most conserved organelle genome and the most widely distributed genome in the tree of life. They also have implications for the evolution of the host–parasite interaction, which is one of the most important interactions in the tree of life.

The 2015–2017 drought in southwestern South Africa was caused by a combination of natural and anthropogenic factors. We show that anthropogenic climate change increased the likelihood of this drought by a factor of five to six. This result is important for the debate on the responsibility of human activities for the current drought and the future risk of drought in SSA. It also highlights the strong sensitivity of the drought risk in SSA to future anthropogenic emissions. The results are important for the design of drought mitigation strategies. The findings are relevant for other regions that are vulnerable to the impacts of climate change.

The discovery of quasicrystals, with their unique properties, has been a major scientific and technological event of the 20th century. The first discovery of a quasicrystal in nature, in the Khatyrka meteorite, was a major scientific event of the 21st century. Here, we report the discovery, in a sample of red trinitite, of a hitherto unknown composition of icosahedral quasicrystal, Si61Cu30Ca7Fe2. This discovery is a major scientific event of the 22nd century.

(Bacterio)chlorophyll biosynthesis is one of the most productive biological pathways on Earth. The formation of the isocyclic fifth ring, the key reaction in the pathway, has remained enigmatic for more than 60 y. This reaction is catalyzed by two unrelated enzymes, one of which is a [4Fe-4S] cluster protein, the other a diiron protein. We show that the diiron protein is a member of a family of enzymes that catalyze the formation of the isocyclic fifth ring in oxygenic and anoxygenic phototrophic bacteria, cyanobacteria, and plants.

Neuroinflammation is a major feature of multiple sclerosis (MS), and neuroinflammation is associated with the development of neurodegenerative diseases. Neuroinflammation is also known to be associated with the activation of mitogen-activated protein kinase kinase kinase, ASK1. In this study, we found that ASK1 plays a critical role in the development of neuroinflammation in EAE. We also found that ASK1 in microglia/macrophages plays a major role in the generation of neuroinflammation, whereas ASK1 in astrocytes plays a major role in the exacerbation of neuroinflammation. Our findings suggest that ASK1 in glial cells plays a critical role in the development and exacerbation of neuroinflammation, and thus, ASK1 may be a promising therapeutic target for reducing neuroinflammation.

The 2012–2014 drought in California was one of the most severe droughts in the state’s history. We show that the probability of drought has increased in the past two decades, and that this increase is attributable to human activities. We also show that the probability of drought has increased because of the interaction between warm and dry conditions. These findings have important implications for water management, ecosystem management, and climate change adaptation.

Autism is a complex disorder with a multifactorial inheritance pattern. Therefore, it is difficult to identify the causal paths that lead to the core autistic symptoms such as social deficit, repetitive behaviors, and behavioral inflexibility. In this study, we used a reversal-learning task to measure behavioral flexibility in Drosophila and determined the effects of loss-of-function mutations in multiple autism-risk gene homologs in flies. We found that mutations of five autism-risk genes with diversified molecular functions all led to a similar phenotype of behavioral inflexibility indicated by impaired reversal-learning. These reversal-learning defects resulted from the inability to forget or rather, specifically, to activate Rac1 (Ras-related C3 botulinum toxin substrate 1)-dependent forgetting. Thus, behavior-evoked activation of Rac1-dependent forgetting has a converging function for autism-risk genes. This study provides a framework for understanding the underlying mechanisms of autism and may facilitate the development of new treatments. (Show more)

This work offers the most comprehensive cross-national demonstration of negativity biases to date, but it also serves to highlight considerable individual-level variation in responsiveness to news content. Insofar as our results make clear the pervasiveness of negativity biases on average, they help account for the tendency for audience-seeking news around the world to be predominantly negative. Insofar as our results highlight individual-level variation, however, they highlight the potential for more positive content, and suggest that there may be reason to reconsider the conventional journalistic wisdom that “if it bleeds, it leads.”

The CRAC channel is a key regulator of cellular Ca2+ signaling, but its physiological role and molecular mechanism of action are not fully understood. Here, we report that mutations in the CRAC channel pore-forming protein and in the Ca2+ sensor of the CRAC channel, which are associated with severe immune dysfunction and myopathy, result in a spectrum of hematological abnormalities. These data expand our understanding of the molecular mechanism of the CRAC channel, and suggest new therapies aiming at attenuating store-operated Ca2+ entry in the treatment of patients with Stormorken syndrome and related pathologic conditions. (Show more)

The spread of protein aggregates is a key feature of many neurodegenerative diseases, but the mechanisms underlying this process are poorly understood. Here we use a model of Huntington’s disease to show that protein aggregates accumulate at synaptic terminals and spread throughout the brain. We show that these aggregates are internalized and accumulate within other neurons, and that this non–cell-autonomous pathology can be prevented by inhibiting endocytosis. Finally, we show that the release of aggregates requires fusion protein 1, demonstrating that active release and uptake of aggregates are important elements of spreading and disease progression. These results provide a model for the spread of protein aggregates in neurodegenerative diseases and may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies. (Show more)

Bats are increasingly recognized as potential reservoirs of many zoonotic viruses. However, the factors that contribute to virus spillover from bats are not well understood. Here, we identified and characterized a protein that is highly concentrated in the submandibular salivary gland of bats, which is highly immunosuppressive and facilitates viral infection. This study provides deeper insight into immunologically privileged sites for microbial community residence in bats and supports the therapeutic potential of targeting the immunosuppressant protein-leukotriene-A4 hydrolase complex. This study also provides a better understanding of the role of the submandibular salivary gland in the immune system of bats and the potential for the submandibular salivary gland to be used as a target for antiviral therapy. (Show more)

Cancer is a disease of cell growth, and thus requires one-carbon units for purine and thymidine synthesis. We show that the one-carbon unit donor, serine, is a critical metabolic target for cancer. We identify a small-molecule inhibitor of both human serine hydroxymethyltransferase 1 and 2, and show that it blocks colon cancer tumor growth. We also show that one-carbon deficiency is a targetable metabolic deficiency of diffuse large B-cell lymphoma, a cancer type that is notoriously difficult to treat. Thus, we have identified a metabolic target for cancer therapy, and a metabolic deficiency for lymphoma therapy. These findings have implications for the treatment of cancer and lymphoma.

Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is a heterogeneous disease with a variety of genetic mutations in proteins that are highly aggregation-prone. These proteins form intracellular inclusion bodies that are characteristic of different neuropathological subtypes of the disease. Here, we show that the proteins that form inclusions in the brain and spinal cord are not merely a subset of the native interaction partners of these three proteins, which are themselves supersaturated. Rather, we observe that they have an average supersaturation even greater than the average supersaturation of the native interaction partners in motor neurons, but not when scores are generated from an average of other human tissues. These results suggest that inclusion bodies in various forms of ALS result from a set of proteins that are metastable in motor neurons, and thus prone to aggregation upon a disease-related progressive collapse of protein homeostasis in this specific setting. This study provides a new perspective on the pathogenesis of ALS and suggests that the disease is caused by a set of proteins that are metastable in motor neurons. This study also provides a new target for therapeutic intervention. (PsycINFO Database Record

We present a 2D photonic crystal system for interacting with cold cesium (Cs) atoms. The band structures of the 2D photonic crystals are predicted to produce unconventional atom–light interaction behaviors, including anisotropic emission, suppressed spontaneous decay, and photon-mediated atom–atom interactions controlled by the position of the atomic array relative to the photonic crystal. The device configuration also enables application of optical tweezers for controlled placement of atoms. Devices can be fabricated reliably from a 200-nm silicon nitride device layer using a lithography-based process, producing predicted optical properties in transmission and reflection measurements. These 2D photonic crystal devices can be readily deployed to experiments for many-body physics with neutral atoms and engineering of exotic quantum matter. The device is expected to be scalable to larger dimensions. The device can be used to study many-body physics in a wide range of systems, including cold atoms, quantum dots, and quantum plasmas. The device can also be used to study the interaction of light with matter in a wide range of systems, including plasmas, quantum dots, and quantum gases. The origin of the flowering plants is one of the most important events in the history of life. The first flowering plants, the angiosperms, are important because they are the dominant plants in many ecosystems today. The first flowering plants are also important because they are the ancestors of many economically important plants, including many important crops. The first flowering plants are known from the Cretaceous, but the origin of the flowering plants is poorly understood. This paper presents a detailed study of a flowering plant from the Cretaceous, Montsechia, and shows that it is the sister group of Ceratophyllum, a living flowering plant that is important in aquatic ecosystems.

The evolution of viruses is of great interest to both virologists and evolutionary biologists. Here we show that the evolution of human parvovirus B19 (B19V) is much slower than previously thought, and we are able to date the origin of B19V to ∼12.6 kya. This study emphasizes the importance of ancient viral sequences for our understanding of virus evolution and phylogenetics. We also show that the recombination event between genotypes 1 and 3 that formed genotype 2 occurred ∼5.0–6.8 kya. This study is of interest to evolutionary biologists, virologists, and archaeologists. (Show more)

Sea level is a sensitive indicator of climate change. In this study, we provide a new estimate of the rate of sea level rise over the last 25 y, which is crucial for understanding the magnitude of the current sea level rise and its future evolution. We find that the rate of sea level rise is accelerating, and the rate of acceleration is increasing. This finding is important for understanding the causes of the acceleration and its implications for future sea level rise.

Pain is a common and costly problem in America today. We show that, for those with less education, pain has increased with age for each successive birth cohort, and that this increase is not explained by changes in occupation or levels of obesity. Instead, it fits a more general pattern seen in the erosion of working-class life for those born after 1950. If this trend continues, pain prevalence will continue to increase for all adults, with potentially serious implications for healthcare.

The study of enzyme mechanisms is a central goal of enzymology. In this work, we use NMR-assisted crystallography to provide a detailed, chemically characterized picture of the structure and dynamics of a key enzyme intermediate. This work highlights the power of NMR-assisted crystallography to provide mechanistic insight into enzyme reactions, and the importance of the chemical environment of the enzyme active site in determining the reaction pathway. This work also highlights the importance of the active site environment in determining the substrate specificity of enzymes. The study of enzyme mechanisms is a central goal of enzymology.

Middle East Respiratory Syndrome (MERS) continues to pose a significant threat to public health. The continued emergence of cases with a high case fatality rate stresses the need for the availability of effective antiviral treatments. Remdesivir (GS-5734) is a broad-spectrum inhibitor of viral RNA synthesis that has been shown to be effective against Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome (SARS)-CoV in a mouse model. Here, we show that prophylactic and therapeutic remdesivir treatment in a nonhuman primate model of MERS-CoV infection provides a clear clinical benefit, with a reduction in clinical signs, reduced virus replication in the lungs, and decreased presence and severity of lung lesions. The data presented here support testing of the efficacy of remdesivir treatment in the context of a MERS clinical trial. It may also be considered for a wider range of coronaviruses, including the currently emerging novel coronavirus 2019-nCoV. This study provides a proof of concept for the use of remdesivir in the treatment of coronaviruses.

The gut microbiota of animals is a major contributor to host health, but the mechanisms by which the host regulates the composition of this community are poorly understood. Here, we show that the provision of a single glycan, chitin, by the host to its symbiotic bacteria is critical for the maintenance of the mutualism. We also show that the glycan is provided only at night, when the host is quiescent, and that the bacteria are required to metabolize the glycan for the host to maintain a healthy symbiosis. These findings suggest that the provision of nutrients, whose catabolism modulates the conditions in the habitat of the symbionts, may be a general mechanism by which animals regulate the composition of their gut microbiota. This mechanism may be particularly important for animals that are active during the day, when the provision of nutrients is most likely to be regulated. (Show more)

This study shows that teachers’ mindsets about discipline can be changed through scalable intervention. The findings have implications for the school-to-prison pipeline, the high rates of suspension and expulsion in schools, and the disproportionate impact of discipline on students of color. The study also has implications for the field of social psychology, which has long focused on the importance of mindsets in shaping behavior. The findings suggest that mindsets can be changed through scalable intervention, and that this change can have important effects on behavior.

DNA alkylation is one of the major causes of DNA damage and mutagenesis. However, the molecular mechanisms of DNA alkylation-induced transcriptional stalling and mutagenesis remain unknown. Here, we systematically investigated the impact of O2-, N3-, and O4-ethylthymidine (EtdT) lesions on the transcription of a lacZ reporter gene. We found that the transcription of the lacZ reporter gene is stalled at the EtdT lesions. The stalling is exacerbated by TFIIS-stimulated proofreading activity. We further identified a minor-groove–sensing motif from pol II, termed Pro-Gate loop, which is involved in modulating the translocation of minor-groove alkylated DNA template after nucleotide incorporation opposite the lesion. Taken together, this work provides important mechanistic insights into transcriptional stalling, lesion bypass, and mutagenesis of alkylated DNA lesions. These findings are of great importance for understanding the impact of DNA alkylation on the accuracy of DNA replication and transcription. They are also of great significance for the development of strategies to mitigate the impact of DNA alkylation on the accuracy of DNA replication and transcription.

Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV) is a zoonotic pathogen that causes severe pneumonia. To better understand the mechanisms of infection, we engineered MERS-CoV to resist sequential proteolysis, which is required for virus entry into cells. We found that the first cleavages, which are required for virus entry, are significant determinants of MERS-CoV virulence. The first cleavages expand virus tropism to cell types that are relevant to lung infection, and therefore may be significant determinants of MERS-CoV virulence.

The food system is a major contributor to global warming and other environmental problems. The food choices of the world’s richest people have a disproportionate impact on the environment compared with those of the world’s poorest people. This study shows that increasing the proportion of vegetarian meals available in a cafeteria can increase the proportion of people choosing vegetarian meals. This is a simple and effective way to reduce the environmental impact of diets, and it is also likely to improve population health. The results suggest that increasing the proportion of vegetarian meals available in catering outlets in the United Kingdom could reduce greenhouse gas emissions by 1.5 million metric tons per year and save 1,000 lives per year. This is equivalent to removing 300,000 cars from the road.

The cell surface proteome is the interface for the cell with the extracellular space. We have developed a method to measure the surface proteome of cells, and applied it to a collection of six oncogenes that are the most common drivers of breast cancer. We find that each oncogene has a different surfaceome, but that the functions of these proteins are harmonized by common biological themes including up-regulation of nutrient transporters, down-regulation of adhesion molecules and tumor suppressing phosphatases, and alteration in immune modulators. These studies provide a broad systems-level view of how specific driver oncogenes remodel the surfaceome and the glycoproteome in a cell autologous fashion, and suggest possible surface targets, and combinations thereof, for drug and biomarker discovery. (Show more)

The COVID-19 pandemic has led to a surge in interest in vote-by-mail programs, which allow voters to cast their ballots by mail. However, the effects of vote-by-mail have not been systematically studied. In this paper, we provide a comprehensive design-based analysis of the effects of vote-by-mail on electoral outcomes. We find that vote-by-mail does not appear to affect either party’s share of turnout, does not appear to increase either party’s vote share, and modestly increases overall average turnout rates. These findings support the conventional wisdom of election administration experts and contradict many popular claims in the media.

The COVID-19 pandemic has highlighted the need for a better understanding of the molecular basis of the disease and the mechanisms by which the virus spreads. Here, we report the structure of the SARS-CoV-2 ORF8 protein, which is proposed to be involved in immune evasion. The structure reveals a unique dimerization interface that is specific to SARS-CoV-2, as well as a second interface that is also unique to SARS-CoV-2. These interfaces may be important for the unique activities of ORF8, including immune evasion and the spread of the virus. These activities may be mediated by the formation of large-scale assemblies of ORF8. The structure of ORF8 provides a starting point for further investigation of the role of ORF8 in the disease and the spread of the virus. (Show more)

Cerebral edema is a potentially life-threatening condition, and knowledge of its underlying mechanisms is limited. Here we show that hypobaric hypoxia induces cerebral edema in rats and that this is associated with an increase in the expression of aquaporin-4 (AQP4), endothelin-1 (ET-1), and corticotrophin releasing factor (CRF) and a decrease in the expression of the CRF receptor type 1 (CRFR1). We also show that, in cultured cortical astrocytes, hypoxia triggers the release of CRF, which acts on CRFR1 to trigger signaling of cAMP/PKA, leading to activation of AQP4 and cerebral edema. These findings provide a molecular basis for the development of cerebral edema and suggest that CRFR1 antagonists may be useful in the treatment of this condition. This study also provides a molecular basis for the development of cerebral edema and suggests that CRFR1 antagonists may be useful in the treatment of this condition. (PsycINFO Database Record

We live in an age of big data, where the size of the data set is large compared to the number of parameters in the model. This makes it difficult to assess the significance of the associations that we find. We describe a new approach to selective inference, which allows us to set a higher bar for declaring significant the associations that we find. We illustrate the new approach in the context of forward stepwise regression, the lasso, and principal components analysis. We believe that the new approach will be useful in many areas of statistical inference.

The generation of endothelial cells (ECs) is a critical step in the development of vascular networks. In this study, we found that ets variant 2 (ETV2) is a key factor for the direct conversion of human adult skin fibroblasts into functional vascular ECs. Our study provides a new strategy for the generation of ECs and the development of vascular networks. This strategy may be useful for the treatment of ischemic disorders and the regeneration of damaged organs. Furthermore, the use of ETV2 may be a promising approach for the treatment of congenital heart disease.

The identification of “orphan” receptor tyrosine kinases (RTKs) with oncogenic potential has led to the development of a number of small-molecule inhibitors. However, the physiological role of these RTKs is unknown. Here, we show that the augmentor ligands of anaplastic lymphoma kinase (ALK) and leukocyte tyrosine kinase (Ltk) are essential for the development of iridophores, a unique type of photoreceptor that is found in the eyes and fins of fish. These experiments establish a physiological link between augmentor ligands and Ltk and demonstrate that particular augmentors activate Ltk in a tissue-specific context to induce iridophore differentiation from neural crest-derived cells and pigment progenitor cells. These findings have implications for our understanding of the function of ALK and Ltk in vivo and for the development of small-molecule inhibitors of these RTKs.

Type 2 diabetes (T2D) is a complex disease with multiple molecular bases. In this study, we found that STING is required for β-cell function and insulin secretion. Specifically, STING deficiency in β-cells caused a decrease in expression of β-cell function–related genes, including Glut2, Kcnj11, and Abcc8, contributing to impaired GSIS. Moreover, Pax6 was identified as a transcription factor that might be associated with defective GSIS in STING-βKO mice. These findings provide insights into the pathophysiology of T2D and suggest a potential target for the treatment of T2D. (Show more)

Influenza A viruses are responsible for the annual influenza epidemics and occasional severe pandemics. The genome of the virus is segmented into eight fragments, which offers evolutionary advantages but complicates genomic packaging. The selective packaging mechanism, in which one copy of each viral RNA is specifically packaged into each virion, is suspected, but its molecular details remain unknown. Here, we identified a direct intermolecular interaction between two viral genomic RNA segments of an avian influenza A virus. We demonstrated that this interaction takes place in infected cells and is required for optimal viral replication. This interaction is sequence-dependent and not widely conserved among influenza A virus. Our experiments indicate that viral RNA segments can promote the selective packaging of the influenza A virus genome by forming a sequence-dependent supramolecular network of interactions. The lack of conservation of these interactions might limit genetic reassortment between divergent influenza A viruses. (Show more)

Atherosclerosis is the leading cause of death worldwide. The development of atherosclerotic lesions is a complex process involving multiple factors. In this study, we focus on the role of Yes-associated protein (YAP)/transcriptional coactivator with PDZ-binding motif (TAZ) in the development of atherosclerotic lesions. We found that YAP/TAZ is activated by disturbed flow, which is a key feature of atheroprone flow. Our results suggest that inhibition of YAP/TAZ activation is a promising strategy for the prevention of atherosclerosis. This study provides a mechanistic understanding of the role of YAP/TAZ in the development of atherosclerotic lesions and may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies for the prevention and treatment of atherosclerosis. (Show more)

Wildfire is a natural process that has shaped the landscape of the United States for millennia. However, the economic and ecological costs of wildfire have risen dramatically in recent decades, and climate change has been blamed for a portion of the increase. We show that the expansion of the fire niche in the United States is largely due to human activities, and that human-caused wildfires are disproportionately concentrated in areas where people live and work. Actions to reduce the risk of wildfire and associated hazards should focus on reducing the number of human-caused wildfires.

We introduce a computer vision method to measure changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods from time-series street-level imagery. We connect changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods with economic and demographic data and find that three factors predict neighborhood improvement: (i) the density of college-educated adults, (ii) the initial appearance of the neighborhood, and (iii) the proximity of the neighborhood to other attractive neighborhoods. Together, our results provide support for three classical theories of urban change and illustrate the value of using computer vision methods and street-level imagery to understand the physical dynamics of cities. Our method can be used to monitor the physical changes in any city over time. We hope that our work will inspire others to use computer vision methods to study the physical dynamics of cities.

Natural repellents are an ecological method of pest control, but their direct molecular targets in arthropods remain to be further elucidated. Here, we identified a scorpion transient receptor potential (sTRP1) channel that senses Cymbopogon-derived natural repellents, while remaining insensitive to the synthetic chemical pesticide DEET. This study sheds light on arthropod molecular targets of natural repellents, exemplifying the arthropod–plant adaptation. It should also help the rational design of insect control strategy and in conserving biodiversity. (Show more)

The recent outbreak of Zika virus (ZIKV) has been associated with neurological complications and fetal abnormalities, prompting global concern. Here we present a mathematical analysis of the within-host dynamics of ZIKV in a nonhuman primate model. We show that the rate of viral production is rapid, and the lifetime of an infected cell while producing virus is ∼5 h. We also show that the median time to undetectable plasma viral load can be reduced from ∼5 d to ∼3 d with a drug concentration ∼15 times the drug’s EC50 when treatment is given prophylactically starting at the time of infection. In the case of favipiravir, a polymerase inhibitor with activity against ZIKV, we predict a dose of 150 mg/kg given twice a day initiated at the time of infection can reduce the peak median viral load by ∼3 logs and shorten the time to undetectable median viral load by ∼2 d. These results can help guide the development of effective antiviral strategies for the control of ZIKV. (Show more)

Coral bleaching is a well-known phenomenon that is often used as a proxy for the health of coral reefs. However, the underlying mechanisms are poorly understood. Here, we show that the breakdown of the coral–algal symbiosis is driven by altered nutrient cycling, which is a consequence of the increased metabolic energy demand of the coral host. This feedback loop is a key factor in the early stages of bleaching and may help to explain the stability of the coral–algal symbiosis in the face of environmental change. Our findings provide a missing link in our understanding of the environmental drivers of bleaching and may ultimately help to predict the fate of coral reefs in a changing climate.

The intestinal epithelium is the main barrier between the host and the external environment. In the presence of tumors, the intestinal barrier is disrupted, leading to systemic infections and organismal death. Here, we show that the tumorigenic loss of BMP signaling leads to a dysbiotic microbiome and a regenerative response, which in turn triggers the activation of JNK signaling and tumor growth. We demonstrate that inhibiting JNK signaling or depleting the microbiome restores barrier function, leading to a reestablishment of host–microbe homeostasis, and organismal lifespan extension. Our work identifies a JNK-dependent feedback amplification loop between intestinal tumors and the microbiome, and it highlights the importance of controlling the activity level of JNK signaling to maintain epithelial barrier function and host–microbe homeostasis. These findings have implications for the development of therapies targeting the tumor–microbiome interaction. They also provide a model for the study of the role of the microbiome in the development of intestinal tumors.

Chemotherapy is a major component of the treatment of breast cancer, but the response to chemotherapy is heterogeneous, and many patients do not respond to treatment. We show that chemotherapy enhances the expression of the type I tyrosine kinaselike orphan receptor ROR1 in breast cancer cells, which may contribute to the development of breast cancer stem cells. We also show that targeting ROR1 with an anti-ROR1 antibody, which is a humanized antibody, may improve the response to chemotherapy in mice bearing breast cancer patient-derived xenografts. These results suggest that targeting ROR1 may be a strategy for improving the response to chemotherapy in patients with breast cancer. (Show more)

The timing of the onset of deglaciation in the Southern Hemisphere is a key piece of the climate puzzle, but the mechanisms are not well understood. We show that a series of volcanic eruptions, exactly at the time of deglaciation, plausibly led to stratospheric ozone depletion and changes in Southern Hemisphere climate, which in turn may have contributed to the acceleration of deglaciation.

Freshwater fisheries are an essential source of food, recreation, and commerce for hundreds of millions of people worldwide. However, they are often overlooked in global assessments of the state of the world’s fisheries. We provide a global map of riverine fisheries, which reveals that 90% of the world’s catch comes from river basins with above-average stress levels. Our analysis also reveals that freshwater fisheries provide the equivalent of all dietary animal protein for 158 million people, particularly in regions where alternative sources of nutrition and employment are scarce. However, the spatial coincidence of productive fisheries and low food security highlights the high stakes for improving fishery management. Our data can facilitate the inclusion of inland fisheries in environmental planning to protect both food security and species diversity.

The development of inherently safe energy devices is a key challenge, and aqueous Li-ion batteries draw large attention for this purpose. However, the narrow electrochemical stable potential window of aqueous electrolytes limits the energy density and the selection of negative electrode materials. Herein, a type of a negative electrode material is proposed for high-energy aqueous Li-ion batteries. The unique nanosized and metastable character of the material is the key to achieve high energy density and safety. This work combines a high capacity with a safe negative electrode material through delivering the Mo-based oxide with unique nanosized and metastable characters. This work provides a new strategy for the development of inherently safe energy devices. This work is expected to be a milestone in the field of aqueous batteries.

The adult mammalian nervous system is incapable of regenerating after injury. This inability is due to the loss of the ability of neurons to regenerate during development, and the lack of a functional regenerative response in the adult. Here, we identify a form of regeneration that is independent of the canonical MAPK signaling cascade, and show that this form of regeneration is linked to a well-studied form of endogenous activity-dependent ectopic axon outgrowth in the same neuron type. These findings provide a unique platform for gene discovery in the regeneration of the adult nervous system.

The process of meiosis is essential for the production of genetically diverse gametes, but the rate of recombination between homologous chromosomes is highly variable across the genome. In this study, we describe the distribution of recombination events in a wild population of the monkeyflower Mimulus guttatus, which provides a natural experiment for the study of recombination in a flowering plant. We find that recombination is more likely to occur near the start of genes than in the middle or end of genes, and that the rate of recombination falls off sharply as one moves away from the start of a gene. These results provide insights into the evolution of recombination in plants and may have implications for the development of new crop plants. (Show more)

The brain is organized in networks of functionally related regions. The present study provides a method for identifying and validating the resting state organization of the human brain, based on the analysis of metabolic activity. This method can be used to identify the resting state organization of the brain in health and disease. The results of this study provide a framework for the development of new imaging methods that can be used to study the organization of the brain in health and disease.

The 5′ cap structure is the most important modification of messenger RNA (mRNA). It is required for efficient translation and is found on all mRNAs that are translated in the cell. Here we describe a second 5′ modification, the nicotinamide-adenine dinucleotide (NAD+) cap, which is found on subsets of nuclear and mitochondrial encoded mRNAs. We show that the NAD+ cap is produced cotranscriptionally and is found on pre-mRNAs, but not on mature mRNAs. This suggests that the NAD+ cap may regulate mRNA stability and translation. Our results provide further evidence for the importance of 5′ modifications in the regulation of gene expression.

The persistence of epigenetic DNA methylation (DNA-me) alterations at specific loci over two different time points in people with diabetes is a novel finding. The results support an epigenetic explanation for metabolic memory, the prolonged beneficial effects of intensive vs. conventional therapy during the Diabetes Control and Complications Trial (DCCT) on the progression of microvascular outcomes in the long-term follow-up Epidemiology of Diabetes Interventions and Complications (EDIC) Study. These findings may also have implications for the understanding of the epigenetic basis of the persistence of DNA-me alterations at specific loci in other diseases.

Triple-negative breast cancer (TNBC) is the most aggressive subtype of breast cancer and is characterized by poor prognosis. In this study, we show that the expression of a protein, known as fibrous sheath interacting protein 1 (FSIP1), is significantly higher in TNBC tissues and is associated with poor prognosis. We also show that FSIP1 deficiency in TNBC cells promotes autophagy, enhances AMP-activated protein kinase (AMPK) signaling, and decreases mechanistic target of rapamycin (mTOR) and Wnt/β-catenin activity. Our findings uncover a role of FSIP1 as well as mechanisms underlying FSIP1 action in drug sensitivity and may, therefore, aid in design of TNBC therapies. (Show more)

Alcohol dependence is a chronic and relapsing disorder that is characterized by a high mortality rate. The present study shows that some alcohol-dependent subjects develop gut leakiness, which is associated with depression, anxiety, and alcohol craving. Moreover, the composition and activity of the gut microbiota are altered in these subjects. These results suggest that the gut microbiota is involved in the development of gut barrier dysfunction and in the behavioral disorders of alcohol dependence. Thus, the gut microbiota seems to be a previously unidentified target in the management of alcohol dependence. This study also provides a possible explanation for the high mortality rate of alcohol dependence. Further studies are needed to test the reversibility of the biological and behavioral parameters after a short-term detoxification program. This may lead to the development of new strategies for the management of alcohol dependence.

The flavor of tomato fruit is a result of the production of a large number of volatile chemicals. These chemicals are produced by a variety of metabolic pathways, including the biosynthesis of nitrogenous compounds. The biosynthesis of these nitrogenous compounds is not known, and the contribution of these compounds to the overall flavor of tomato fruit is unknown. Here we report the identification of a gene essential for the production of all the nitrogenous volatiles in tomato fruit. We also report the identification of a pathway for the production of these compounds, which is unique to tomato fruit. This work provides a major step forward in understanding the flavor of tomato fruit and will be of interest to researchers in the fields of biochemistry, plant biology, and flavor chemistry. (Show more)

The loss of biodiversity and the warming of the planet are two of the most profound threats to the functioning of ecosystems. We show that the impacts of these two threats on ecosystem functioning are not independent of each other. We demonstrate that the impacts of warming on the relationship between biodiversity and ecosystem functioning are driven by changes in the thermal tolerance of species. This finding has important implications for the future of ecosystems, as it suggests that the impacts of biodiversity loss and environmental warming on ecosystem functioning are likely to be synergistic. Our results highlight the importance of considering the thermal tolerance of species when assessing the impacts of climate change on the functioning of ecosystems. This is critical for understanding the future of the world’s biodiversity and the services it provides.

The medial entorhinal cortex (MEC) is a critical hub for navigation, and its functional organization is poorly understood. Here, we used a portable two-photon microscope to record the activity of neurons in the MEC of freely moving mice. We found that grid cells, which are thought to be responsible for the formation of a map of local space, are strongly coupled among themselves but weakly coupled to other cell types. These findings suggest that grid cells might form a network that is largely distinct from those of other cell types. Our results provide a detailed view of the organization of the MEC and its relation to navigation. They also provide a platform for future studies of the functional organization of the MEC. This platform will be useful for understanding the role of the MEC in navigation and other cognitive functions.

Flowering is a complex process that is controlled by a large number of genes. In this study, we show that the flowering signal FLOWERING LOCUS T (FT) is required for flowering of the host plant, which is a prerequisite for flowering of the parasitic dodder. This study demonstrates that FTs can function as an important interplant flowering signal in host–parasite interactions. The unique means of flowering regulation of the dodder illustrates how regressive evolution, commonly found in parasites, may facilitate the physiological synchronization of parasite and host, here allowing the C. australis parasite to time reproduction exactly with that of their hosts, likely optimizing parasite fitness. This study also provides a model for understanding the evolution of flowering regulation in plants. This work may also have implications for the study of flowering in general.

Parkinson’s disease is caused by the degeneration of neurons in the substantia nigra pars compacta, which are responsible for the production of the neurotransmitter dopamine. The disease is characterized by a loss of motivation and movement, and the loss of dopamine-producing neurons is thought to be the cause of these symptoms. Here, we show that the neurons that produce dopamine in the substantia nigra are connected to other brain regions, including the striatum, through a system of specialized structures. These structures, which we call “striosome–dendron bouquets,” are likely to be critical to the function of the dopamine system in health and disease.

We are often told that we should “click” with someone, but how do we know when we do? We conducted a large-scale study of 1,000 people in six closed networks to find out. We found that the speed with which people respond to each other is a robust predictor of how connected people feel to each other. This signal is used by third-party listeners to predict how connected people are to each other, and it is used by people to predict how connected they are to each other. Together, these findings suggest that response times comprise a robust and sufficient signal of whether two minds “click.”

The sinoatrial node (SAN) is the primary pacemaker of the heart. SAN automaticity is regulated by specialized cardiomyocytes, which are responsible for generating the heart rate. We report here that stromal interaction molecule 1 (STIM1), a regulator of Ca2+ stores, is expressed in the SAN and plays a critical role in the regulation of SAN automaticity. Our results reveal that STIM1 regulates SAN automaticity by modulating the activity of the plasma membrane ion channels. These findings provide insights into the molecular mechanisms that govern SAN function and may lead to the development of new strategies for the treatment of heart failure. (Show more)

Silicon (Si) is an essential element for plant growth and development, but its role in plant defense against insect herbivores has not been well characterized. Here, we show that Si pretreatment of rice plants increases resistance against the rice leaffolder, a major insect pest of rice, and that this effect is mediated by the jasmonate (JA) signaling pathway. Our results suggest that Si and JA interact to promote plant defense against insect herbivores. This study provides insights into the role of Si in plant defense and may lead to the development of Si-based strategies for insect pest management. (Show more)

The lipidome of macrophages is a key factor in the regulation of inflammation and immune response. The lipid metabolism of macrophages is also important for the metabolism of other cells, such as neurons, and for the regulation of the brain–immune system interaction. Here we show that tetrahydrobiopterin, a cofactor of nitric oxide synthesis, is important for the metabolism of ether lipids in macrophages. We also show that the activity of a key enzyme in ether lipid metabolism, alkylglycerol monooxygenase, is important for the regulation of the immune response. These findings provide a basis for further studies on the role of tetrahydrobiopterin and alkylglycerol monooxygenase in the regulation of the lipidome and the immune response.

Language is a highly complex system that involves the integration of information over time. Here we propose a mechanism for memory in the brain that is based on the adaptive changes in the firing rate of neurons. This mechanism is sensitive to context and serial order, and it is sensitive to the duration of the memory. This work provides a step toward a computational neurobiology of language.

The delivery of biomolecules to plants is a critical step in the development of plant-based biotechnologies. Here, we report the delivery of siRNAs to plants using DNA nanostructures. We show that the size, shape, compactness, stiffness, and location of the siRNA attachment locus on the DNA nanostructure are important design parameters for the delivery and gene silencing efficiencies. Our work establishes the feasibility of DNA nanostructures for the delivery of biomolecules to plants and also details the design parameters of importance for plant cell internalization and also assesses the impact of DNA nanostructure geometry for gene silencing mechanisms. This work will be useful for the development of plant-based biotechnologies.

The world’s largest freshwater bodies are threatened by nutrient pollution, which is driven largely by nonpoint sources from tributaries draining surrounding watersheds. We show that the majority of nutrient loads to the world’s fifth largest lake, Lake Michigan, are delivered by a small fraction of its tributaries. Although the largest tributaries are the most important in terms of total loads, the nutrient loads from smaller tributaries are high for their size and biased toward dissolved inorganic forms. This suggests that nutrient inputs from small tributaries may be more likely to fuel algal blooms in the nearshore zone, where these large water bodies are most valuable for recreation and commerce. Our findings highlight the importance of small tributaries in driving coastal nutrient pollution and provide a framework for targeting nutrient management efforts to reduce the ecological impacts of nutrient pollution in large water bodies.

We study the dynamics of a simple chemical network in the presence of a strong environmental forcing. We find that the long-time dynamics of such systems are biased toward states that exhibit a fine-tuned extremization of environmental forcing. This behavior is reminiscent of the “optimal fluctuation” phenomenon in physics, where the environment exerts a force on a system in order to maximize the entropy production. We discuss the implications of our results for the study of the dynamics of complex networks and for the understanding of the origin of the long-time dynamics of complex systems.

The role of the brain’s electrical activity in the genesis of seizures is well established, but the mechanisms by which the electrical activity of the brain can predispose to seizures are poorly understood. Here we show that the presence of an autoimmune antibody against a critical synaptic receptor can change the electrical activity of the brain, and that this change can predispose the brain to paroxysmal activity. These findings offer insights into the mechanisms by which the electrical activity of the brain can predispose to seizures. They also suggest that the electrical activity of the brain may be a useful biomarker for the presence of autoimmune encephalitis. This work may also have implications for the treatment of autoimmune encephalitis.

The history of carbon (C) perturbations throughout Earth’s history has been used to understand the response of the Earth system to abrupt warming. However, most studies focused on short-term warming events superimposed on longer-term greenhouse climate states. Here, we present an integrated proxy (carbon and uranium [U] isotopes and paleo CO2) and multicomponent modeling approach to investigate an abrupt C perturbation and global warming event (∼304 Ma) that occurred during a paleo-glacial state. We show that the event can be linked to an injection of organic matter–derived C and to near 20% of areal extent of seafloor anoxia. The event is linked to enhanced thermocline stratification and nutrient fluxes during an icehouse. This work provides insights into the history of C perturbations and the response of the Earth system to abrupt warming. (Show more)

The Roundtable on Sustainable Palm Oil (RSPO) is the most widely used certification scheme for palm oil. We show that RSPO certification reduces deforestation in oil palm plantations, but the impact is small and limited to areas that are already degraded. Certification has no causal impact on forest loss in peatlands or active fire detection rates. Broader adoption of certification in forested regions, strict requirements to avoid all peat, and routine monitoring of clearly defined forest cover loss in certified and RSPO member-held plantations appear necessary if the RSPO is to yield conservation and climate benefits from reductions in tropical deforestation. Our results highlight the need for certification schemes to be more effective in reducing deforestation and fire in the remaining forest of the world.

The exocytosis process is essential for the transport of proteins and vesicles from the endoplasmic reticulum to the plasma membrane. The exocytosis process is regulated by the exocyst complex, which is conserved from bacteria to humans. The exocyst complex is composed of 10 subunits, of which the EXO70 subunit is the most important. We discovered that the small molecule Endosidin2 (ES2) binds to the EXO70 subunit of the exocyst complex, resulting in inhibition of exocytosis and endosomal recycling in both plant and human cells and enhancement of plant vacuolar trafficking. This study provides a valuable tool in studying exocytosis regulation and a potentially new target for drugs aimed at addressing human disease. (Show more)

The genetic basis of sex determination is a key component of the evolution of sexual dimorphism, and the number of sexes an organism can have is a fundamental property of species diversity. Here we show that the number of sexes in a species can be modulated by the number of alleles that interact to determine sex. This modularity of sex determination can result in the gain or loss of secondary sexual characteristics, and the introgression of new alleles can create new axes of variation for sexual traits. These results have implications for the evolution of sexual dimorphism and the maintenance, gain, or loss of sex determination alleles in populations.

The retina is a unique organ that is challenged by the accumulation of reactive oxygen species- and light-generated photoproducts of lipids. These photoproducts, collectively known as lipofuscin, are a major cause of vision loss. We show that the levels of iron in the retina, as reflected in the transferrin receptor, impact the levels of lipofuscin. This finding is important because iron is a key component of the Fenton reaction, which is the source of reactive oxygen species in the retina. Thus, the levels of iron in the retina may impact the levels of lipofuscin, which in turn may impact vision. This work provides a mechanistic understanding of the role of iron in the retina and may lead to the development of new therapies to treat vision loss. (PsycINFO Database Record

Predators are the key to understanding the structure of food webs, and the evolution of their feeding strategies is fundamental to the study of the origin and diversification of life. However, the evolution of specialization is often considered a dead end, as it is associated with the loss of morphological and functional optimizations. Here we show that the evolution of specialization in siphonophores, a group of pelagic cnidarians, is linked to the evolution of morphological and functional optimizations in separate structures. Our findings contribute to a broader perspective on the evolution of specialization, and help understand how morphological evolution has shaped present-day food webs.

The evolution of the human hand is a key area of research in human evolution. This study provides the earliest unambiguous evidence for the evolution of a key derived feature of the human hand, the third metacarpal styloid process. This finding suggests that the distinctive complex of radial carpometacarpal joint features in the human hand arose early in the evolution of the genus Homo and probably in Homo erectus sensu lato. This study also provides a new perspective on the evolution of the human hand in the context of the evolution of the genus Homo. Together, these findings provide new insights into the evolution of the human hand and its relationship to the evolution of the genus Homo. (Show more)

Cancer cells have a high demand for one-carbon units, which are required for the synthesis of nucleic acids. We have developed a small-molecule inhibitor of serine hydroxymethyltransferase (SHMT), a key enzyme in this pathway. We have shown that this inhibitor is effective in blocking the growth of colon cancer xenografts in mice. We have also shown that this inhibitor is effective in blocking the growth of lymphoma cell lines. Thus, this inhibitor may be useful in the treatment of cancer.

The world is facing a double burden of malnutrition, with a growing number of people suffering from both undernutrition and micronutrient deficiencies. In this study, we show that deforestation can have a negative impact on people’s diets, and that this impact is exacerbated when people have less access to natural landscapes such as forests. Our findings have important implications for policy makers, who should consider the role of natural landscapes in improving people’s diets, particularly in rural areas of low- and middle-income countries. Our study also highlights the need for further research on the role of natural landscapes in improving people’s diets, particularly in low- and middle-income countries.

Modern agriculture is a major contributor to global food production, but it comes at a cost to the soil, which is being compacted to the point of ecological failure. This study shows that the weight of modern farm machinery has increased so much that the subsoil is now being compacted to the point of ecological failure. We show that the weight of modern farm machinery is now approaching that of the largest animals that walked Earth, the sauropods. We hypothesize that the roaming of sauropods would have had similar adverse effects on land productivity as modern farm vehicles, suggesting that ecological strategies for reducing subsoil compaction, including fixed foraging trails, must have guided these prehistoric giants. Our findings have important implications for the design of farm machinery and the management of agricultural practices to ensure the sustainability of modern agriculture. They also suggest that the weight of farm machinery may have been a limiting factor in the evolution of sauropods.
